content:
Posted: April 22, 2016
												I bought this game a good bit ago before they added multiplayer or any of the other 'new' things they've released. And even after they added these updates it just made the game better. Heres what a typical player would do: Start, skip the tutorial, get the basic tools for your little buds, and go to town mining, chopping trees, fighting enemies, etc etc. I just don't understand how people can complain about such a fantastic game.. There is nothing wrong with the combat, its entirely straight forward and simple, you click and tell your slaves to attack and they attack, most of the time wrecking the ♥♥♥♥ out of anything that attacks them. I started off and got myself 5 dwarves before the first medusa cyclops eye monster came and they all had basic clubs in their hands when they ran to fight it, know what happened? THEY ♥♥♥♥ED IT UP!!!And on to the mining and chopping, its tedious, not gonna lie about that. Your slaves will run around and act all derpy and take 2 hours to go and place a ♥♥♥♥ing torch or put down a ladder, but thats just because they prioritize certain things like fighting or mining something before they prioritize placing a torch or ladder. There is NOTHING wrong with their system of prioritization, its pretty damn good! Over all i'd give this game a very nice 8/10.Why? because its a fun♥♥♥♥♥game and i like to kill zombies with a bunch of slaves! XD

content:
Posted: April 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is an Easrly Access game, but as soon as you press the "play" button, it will be almost forgoten. Craft the World is about you controlling/commanding your little dwarf tribe, building/expanding your shelter, collecting resources that will help you keep dwarves fed and fresh, always "begging" you for some more work. That sounds simple enought, but there is some more depth to the game. Monsters, like zombies and skeletons, roam around mostly at night, goblins may camp nearby and propably will raid you and even more horrifiying creatures dwell deep under the ground. On top of that, every 50 or so minutes a wave of monsters will appear on the map at night. You will have to survive till the morning. The waves will get stronger as you level up. Oh, did i say that you lvl up? Well, sure you do. You gain experience constructing new buildings or armor, mining, chopping down trees, killing enemies etc. For every level you gain, you get one more dwarf under your commands. You can micromanage every dwarf (i m currently level 10, with 10 dwarves), in a pretty simple and easy way, applying to them new armor sets, weapons, mining and logging tools and stuffs with special properties that increase their ability in certain things. Every dwarf can have 3 specializations, from crafting or mining faster, to dealing more damage to enemies. There are many more things concerning the depth of the game, but i ll leave it up to you. Of course, there are some issues with the UI and some minor bugs, but having in mind that this is an Early Acces game, it is well done till this point. Currently i m on a campaign mode, playing the first map and have spend 20 hours on just that. I nealry have completed all the skills tree and there are many more things to do. Reading negative reviews from players with only 2 hours on this game, is a great great facepalm.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2016
												A Great fun game of Terraria / Dungeon Keeper / Lemmings. Spent about 14 hours to beat the first of four "Level" and had a lot of fun. Thinking I would roll into the second level with increased difficulty and a modest stash from my first world I was left in shock to find out that absolutely nothing carried over. Not feeling on spending another few days trying to do the exact thing over again I tried the "New" multiplayer (6 month old at time of writing) with a friend and, again, we had a lot of fun. It was confusing that somehow I had my units and supply from my singleplayer but my partner had a fully unlocked tech tree, eventually the same problem as single player that when we had to call it a night we lost everything and couldn't return to the game we spent 5+ hours in together. TLDR; 3.5 / 5Buy it on sale +Great fun for a single playthrough, 8-12 hours-Minor Bugs-No replayability or proper multiplayer co-op

												This is what Terraria should have been. It's side-scrolling survival, but with multiple units that turn it into a real-time strategy game. content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												I am a fan of succinct and to the point reviews. I will do my best to adhere to my own rules with this review.Pros: - Technology tree is awesome- Graphics are extremely well done (specifically the environment/textures/objects). Though I found the character sprites a bit on the cartoonish side (including the enemies - just a minor personal gripe).- Enough going on to keep you busy for several hours.- I loved the idea of an Altar/Shrine!Cons:- Crafting interface is unforgivable. You must drag and drop each instance of the resource required. WHAT? Whose idea was that?- Not enough to work towards (while my own time with this game was brief - I was able to get a good sense of this aspect by watching several in-depth YouTube reviews)- No risk/reward mechanism. You won't really die if a ginormous Zombie smacks you around and falls on you! I prefer challenge and some sense of realism!- The world needs to be much much bigger. Think Terraria sized worlds.- You can't truly take control over the characters. Sorry, I like full control Yes, I am a control freak when it comes to these kind of games.Overall I feel this game needs a lot of improvement to get it to where it needs to be.In the meantime I will get my fix by playing Terraria!

content:
Posted: June 1, 2015
												Really bad game, but you'd be forgiven for thinking that it might be anything decent. The game does have pretty good presentation and art, but the actual gameplay is probably not what you're expecting.Personally I was thinking that this might be like dwarf fortress, but it has nothing to do with management. It's more like a 2D horde survival game where you don't control the characters directly, and you exploit the surrounding countryside for stuff to craft into tools or weapons or even blocks.Every night a horde of undead will try to assault your holdings. It does sound fun maybe, but there's just too many  restrictions put into place. You can't place traps and since you can't control your dwarfs directly you pretty much end up staring at them mucking about trying to exploit or fight for you.The game is very slow paced which might be neither good or bad depending on what type of player you are, but you're probably going to feel that there's just not a lot of interesting things for you to do in the game. It's simply a boring, boring game. If you're a migrating DF player like me - then I definitely don't recommend this game. If you however are looking for a very slow paced 2D shooteresque game with light management elements in it - then this might be for you. Regardless I don't give this my personal recommendation.

content:

												I really gave this a shot. I restarted more than twice, just trying to get through the tutorial level. And... nevermind that the requirements for a *basic* shelter are really hard to satisfy, I wasn't having any fun. Everything takes forever, and not in a "I am living in a simulation" satisfying way.I had dwarves coming out my rear before I could build a shelter - the basic walls of which are apparently advanced technical knowledge; in this universe, iron forging is less complicated than shoving some logs together - and the shelter stopped working if I tried to add new levels or dig underneath or... well, anything that games like Terraria solved literally years ago. I keep seeing people saying they had fun with this, and I'm genuinely at a loss. The tutorial doesn't work right. You can't build basic shelters until after you've discovered the Bessemer process. Just... why?

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								Looking at the trailer, which played at "light speed" mode, made a good impression on me that the game looks fun.Here is my little tales after picking up the game, played it for an hour.And the first bad thing I notice is the said game speed itself.I don't mind much the dwarfs working so slooowwwwly. But the pacing of their movements leave a bad taste in my mouth. Imagine buying iron ores from the shop, which was 2 screens away, which I didnt expect the bought items to drop on the floor like that. Now I'd have to wait.... for certain worker to decide that "OH THERE ARE SOMETHING I COULD PICK UP THERE", then wait for a few more minutes for them to walk, again, slowly. to the shop. pickup items. "OH, the bag is full, I should go back"...... Then after arriving at the base, it'd have been night, which I'd have to lock the house for the safe of the party.The night was passed by, slowly, something like  5 or more minutes of unable to do anything.... because it was night time, with peril monsters and ghost wondering around. I really wished I could dig down the house to do something below... but it was not possible due to the prohibition during the night. Ah, well, zzzzzzzzzz............the new dawn has come, with the light of the sun, the darkness was gone. The dwarfs went out on their journey. I hoped for them to go and take the ore I had bought yesterday.... but NO. They like the woods and stones dropped nearby, so they all went in another direction, slowly, to get something I dont really need at the time, without a way for me to say "HEY YOU RED, GO THERE!"And thus I closed the game... hoping the bad cloud in my mind would dissappear when I went back for the game, one more time, some time.Maybe.Hopefully.At the current state, I'd not recommeneded the game to anyonem looking for some Terraia HD. I shall see again after some more updates from devs.....

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												Craft The World looks very nice, but unfortunately, it wasn't what I was looking for. It possesses the same problem which caused me to abandon attempts to play Terraria: there is simply too little complexity in game's world, so in the end procedural stories do not quite happen.Quite simply, CtW isn't "simplified Dwarf Fortress", but rather "Terraria with Somewhat Indirect Control". While you (usually) do not take direct control of any single dwarf (although there is such an option, and it's often helpful), your dwarves show very little signs of thinking for themselves. They have no mental model like those of DF, and they certainly seem far more simple than, say, heroes in old Majesty game. Watching them is plainly boring, because they rarely do things for themselves, but only hurry to complete tasks you set for them, idling or sleeping when there is nothing to do.Also, this is a game about DWARVES where said dwarves do not quite care for BEER and only brew it for a very slight food value at high level of technology. WTF?!I guess CtW isn't a BAD game per se. Maybe it suits someone who likes management games, or something else which I don't like. I would refrain from marking my review as positive or negative if I could. Just don't expect it, like I did, to see an independently living world in it.On a positive side, I must remark that this game is REALLY beautiful, and sound of birdsong is very nice too :)

content:
Posted: May 31, 2016



YouTube™ Video: Craft The World 5 Minute Review 

			Views: 646		

			Buy it now on Steam! Or don't...		

Tl;dr; Not a bad game, but somewhat slow en tedious on the crafting level. Darf AI isn't too great either with them getting stuck or just left clueless often. Multiplayer is a true grief-fest, but what did you want? Fun to play if you can live with its flaws.----------------So it's all about crafting a world for you dwarves. They have opened a portal which only had the power to transport 1 brave pioneer into your playfield and depend on your guidance to prosper and thrive. That is, if you can hold off the forces of evil that come out every night and every 45 minutes (the Devil sure is punctual).To do so you need to gather resources by clicking on them. After that your eager dwarves will mine or hack away and carry the stuff back to the stockpile where it can be used to craft new items/base decorations/fortifications/food/...Sadly not all dwarves are born with an Einstein level intellect so you will be wondering why 1 of them (let's call him Toby) is always doing the exact opposite of what you want. Be prepared to bail Toby out a lot with portals, scaffolding and ladders.Building the actual shelter is pretty basic and not too refreshing. The only real notable thing is the aura of the "Totem". The more comfort you give the dwarves, the larges their base will become. Which in turn gives you more space for more dwarves.You get new darves by leveling up through crafting, completing tasks and combat. It somehow makes it feel too much like a mobile game by doing this, but then again every other comparable game does it... Leveling is pretty fast in the beginning but slows down incredibly after lvl 10, however the monster waves don't.So you day to day management will be:-  gather resources- craft what you need for new technologies- give dwarves new items- expand baseSounds like a lot of fun? Well it is in the beginning... but after a while you need to craft 100 fancy chairs just to be able to pass on to Steel armour. It makes no sense to me, uses up a lot of resources and especially slows things down dramatically. The first "easy" world will take quite a while to complete, even with cheats...And then there's multiplayer... for the love of God or Buddha or whoever you wish to believe in, do it with friends or alone. Chances are random players will screw you over beyond belief sending you right back to your tedious crafting without any reward whatsoever.So all in all I want to really like the game for its ideas and just because I love the genre, but I'm stuck just barely liking it because some things can be too frustrating. If you can get it on a decent sale then don't doubt, otherwise there are better alternatives.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is a LOT of fun. I've found myself unable to put it down once I start. One thing you have to keep in mind while playing it is that it is an early release game and so there are a few things that are a little quirky here or there. With that in mind, I'd like to make a few suggestions (if anyone in the development team is reading these):1. When you are able to control the dwarves, give some options to put them into gather mode and then allow the user to click an area that you want them to gather. I've found that often times if you have multiple areas being worked on, the dwarves will not gather what has been chopped down/killed/etc. And if you control a dwarf and bring him to the area it is hit or miss as to whether he will gather the materials there. That's a bit aggrivating when you are low on iron and there is a bunch of it on the ground that they have mined.2. Add a warp feature where you can speed up time. As others have said, on large maps it takes a long time to watch your dwarves go from one area to another. If you could speed up the clock by 2x, 3x, 4x, and finally 5x multipliers that should solve the issue.3. Give the option to craft a new supply hub/portal. This way the dwarves could bring it to multiple locations and remove some of the time it takes to get from one to the other. Another idea might be instead of creating multiple supply hubs, to give a permanent teleportation base that ports you back to the main hub (much like the spell) that could be crafted and multiple dwarves could simply walk through it.These are just a few things that I've noticed so far (fairly new to the game) but overall I am really LOVING this game. I would recommend it to anyone that likes these types of games. Check it out!

One thing you have to keep in mind while playing it is that it is an early release game and so there are a few things that are a little quirky here or there. With that in mind, I'd like to make a few suggestions (if anyone in the development team is reading these):1. When you are able to control the dwarves, give some options to put them into gather mode and then allow the user to click an area that you want them to gather. I've found that often times if you have multiple areas being worked on, the dwarves will not gather what has been chopped down/killed/etc. And if you control a dwarf and bring him to the area it is hit or miss as to whether he will gather the materials there. That's a bit aggrivating when you are low on iron and there is a bunch of it on the ground that they have mined.2. Add a warp feature where you can speed up time. As others have said, on large maps it takes a long time to watch your dwarves go from one area to another. If you could speed up the clock by 2x, 3x, 4x, and finally 5x multipliers that should solve the issue.3. Give the option to craft a new supply hub/portal. This way the dwarves could bring it to multiple locations and remove some of the time it takes to get from one to the other. Another idea might be instead of creating multiple supply hubs, to give a permanent teleportation base that ports you back to the main hub (much like the spell) that could be crafted and multiple dwarves could simply walk through it.These are just a few things that I've noticed so far (fairly new to the game) but overall I am really LOVING this game. I would recommend it to anyone that likes these types of games. Check it out!

content:
Posted: July 31, 2015
												"Don't judge a game you've never played"  or "Don't judge a game by photos"I've seen this game surface on steam and never quite saw any interest given by the pictures.  Why I never went to youtube to see what the game was about is beyond me.  Craft The World is by far the most addictive game I've come across since Plants vs Zombies (1), Field Runners and Prison Architect.  I woke up one morning, played all day and night around the clock till 6am.  That's how addictive this game is.  The whole minecraft, side scroller/builder is awesome.  I never thought something like this would be so much fun.  Albeit it needs more updates with bugs and a few new ideas; this game is amazing.  I can't say much about it.  For $10, it's a damn steal.  You must try this game without asking questions.  Remember, Cash shop is not pay to win, to gather water you need buckets in your inventory and just click on the water and choose gather or fish.  Just a couple of stuff I came across I couldn't figure out and felt stupid how much of a common sense it was.5/5

content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								Played the games for some hours and had fun playing it. Despite that I would not recommend this game (at this development stage) as the game has a steep learning curve compared to other games. In a regular game nowadays you will get the time to learn step by step what you need, how to get it, etc. In this game it is all trial and error. As the game is still being developed I hope that the developers will choose to make some changes to make it more "builder" friendly.The game revolves around getting building materials and getting increasing access to more advanced buildings. Before the first night falls, you will at least need a basic shelter to not get your dwarves killed right away. The way the game incrementially intoduces you to new buildings and craftable objects is good as you will not get overwhelmed by the possibilities (which are huge). With every object built you unlock the next object.Besides the building the game lets you also encounter enemies. As these enemies already come at the first night, there is no opportunity to relax and take your time to build a fort or solid defense. As you play the game more often you will find it easier to know how to quickly get the resources you need. One of the resources I have been lacking quite often is wood.All things considered I'm in the middle of rating it positive or negative. At the current stage it is slightly negative but I'm confident that the developers will sway my vote to positive with some slight changes to game mechanics.

number of helpful: 0 of 5 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2015
												Have you ever wanted to be suckered into buying a mobile device game on your PC?  Are you tired of the subtle humor and gameplay for all ages in things like Terraria and looking for something that will give you tedium and a complete lack of control?  Craft The World is the game for you!Gone are the days where you have to do all that pesky mining yourself in a matter of seconds!  Gone are the days where your construction is in an open world and the universe is your oyster!  Imagine, for a moment, some of the greatest games in strategy platformer gaming history.  The Lemmings. The Humans.  Now imagine all of the aspects of those games that made you want to pull your hair out, and here we are!I picked this up because Steam recommended it because Terraria.   This has paid off before..Starbound, Edge of Space, etc.  This game plays nothing like those.  Instead, you have command of a dwarf or two and give them commands to build stuff and harvest resources.  What shows that this was originally a mobile game?  You wait.  And wait.  Then there's more waiting.   In 10 minutes I had done 5 things.  3 of those were in another window.  I'm not sure why this was so highly recommended, as my opinion of this game is that it is microtransaction tripe ported to PC with all of the appeal of recycled laxatives.

number of helpful: 9 of 24 people (38%) found this review helpful18 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												SEX!Huzah!  Now I have your attention.As far as God-simulators go, this game is pretty awesome.  The game has a surprising amount of depth and a creative sandbox mode once you complete the 3 level campaign which adds to the fun.  The campaign consists of 3 levels: first is a small forest setting, the second is a medium sized snow setting, and the last is a large desert, each getting more difficult to pass.  Don't be fooled by the few levels though, each one has taken me upwards of 10 hours each to finish.Over the course of a game, you have to start with nothing much like other creation games such as Minecraft, and build your way up from nothing by gathering everything from dirty to iron, gold, and eventually Mithril.  Using these gathered resources, you traverse a large tech tree, each category allowing you to build more items ranging from decoration for your home to weapons and armor.The game will pique your interest quick and hold your attention for a long time.  With that said, once you beat the campaign and do a sandbox mode or two, you start to notice and exploit things like how to efficiently mine, find gold or skill books, and how to cheese the invading zombies (I will not reveal that here.)  Once this happens, you (or at least I did) will get bored quickly.  The novelty for me wore off literally halfway through a game one day, and I just quit.The Good:1-Great crafting system2-Challenging combat (not at first, but the longer you stay in game, the more enemies come out to ransack you)3-very fun spellunking system4-hours upon hours of fun per level5-quests give you both direction and rewardThe Bad:1-Once you've discovered combat and mining exploits, the game loses most of its fun and challenge2-Even the largest maps are pretty small, taking maybe only 25% more time to finish than the smallest3-Enemy waves happen only once every 50 minutes (25 minutes if you have the game speed set to 2x)4-weapon and armor improvements are WAY down the tech tree, so you have inferior gear against large waves if you dont move fastAll in all, the game is a great way to burn a lot of hours, especially for how cheap it is.  being under $20 means that as long as you enjoy it for at least 10 hours, it was well worth it, and I promise you will get a lot more than that out of it.

												ПОСОНЫ НЕ ПОКУПАЙТЕ ТАМ ЗАВИСИМОСТЬ ОТ ИГРЫ ТРИ ДНЯ НИЧЕГО НЕ ЕЛ И ПОЧТИ НЕ СПАЛ!!!Данная игра приглянулась мне довольно давно, На ператке я играл в нее часов двадцать и решил ее купить, ну достижения, часы вобщем не советую ее покупать тем людям у которых нету терпения, целеустремленности, уметь успокоиться и понять суть этой игры.Приглянувшиеся особенностикрасивая графика, которая не тормозит.  приятная музыка.сложная система крафта.огромным миры, на освоение каждого из которых нужен не один час.гномы, каждый со своими особенностями, навыками и внешностью.волны врагов, приходящих по ночам.До сих пор в игре есть некоторые неровности, например, гномы порой не могут найти нужный путь или постройки для дома не подсвечивают количество клеток, которые займут, от чего поначалу дико неудобно их размещать внутри здания, да и постройка этого самого здания не очень подробно описана в документации.Тем не менее, на все эти мелочи перестаёшь обращать внимание уже на третий час игры, сосродотачиваясь на более интересных вещах.Денис Слепенчук

Early Access Review
								I don't like how much resources it takes to build even a simple shelter, and after a few days of having no shelter, your dwarves are at such low health that you can't do anything thanks to them constantly running away from enemies that don't leave your shelter (And thus, your stockpile, and any beds you may have tried to place but refuse to work, thanks to the aforementioned lack of resources to build a shelter.)This game would be so much better with a pre-made shelter, so that your dwarves have somewhere to get back to every night where they don't have to run from enemies.

number of helpful: 0 of 7 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10, 2016
												I'd like to recommend this game but the AI is truly broken.  The dwaves will run around in a panic and not rest or eat.  They run into monsters and do nothing.  They stand around doing nothing when there is all kinds of goods to pick up.   Dwarves will walk into enemy camps and do nothing while the enemy beats the stuffing out of them.  I'll open a portal for them to get to safety and they just stand there instead of using the portal and going to safety.  Dwarves will seal themselves into a chamber without figuring the right order to put the blocks down to ensure they can get out.  Dwarves will fall into water and drown unless you can take manual control and get them out.    Loot will just inexplicably disappear from the map.  CRTL R - Supposed to make all dwarves rest that are under 70% health.  They are at their beds standing next to it and momentarily make a snoring sound.  But they are tired and won't lie down.  Same problem if you slect them individually and tell them to go rest so they can heal.  They'll just stand there.CRTL E - all hungry dwarves are supposed to eat.  They don'tYou can select them individually and try and get them to do one of those things when they are getting the crap kicked out of them, or if they are standing around doing nothing.  Not going to work though.Other problems not bugs but just present game features - If you click on attack every dwarf no matter where they are will ALL run to the one enemy.  There's really no way to assign individual dwarves to tasks.  They just do them based on what the AI decides.There's no way to sell or stuff you mine to the merchant for goods, except for gold coins that you randomly find.You'll find yourself constantly running out of resources, so a trade system (even an unbalanced one) would be helpfulKeyboard interaction is limited.  You will find yourself clicking, and double clicking to select a resources.  You want to select a certain dwarf - you must click on the dwarf.On a postive note:Pretty graphics.Developer seems like a nice guy.  He notes the bugs I report but no response on an update or a known issue. So, the game is pretty much unplayable in it's present state unless you just want to manually control each dwarf that has become unresponsive and walk them into a monster and let them die.  Then you'll get another one after a while.  But you will start from scratch and lose the skills the dwarf has aquired.  If you don't do thist, your unresponsive dwarf will either run around amlessly until is gets killed and you will lose the equipment you made for it (about 80% change of that), or it will just stand there and do absolutely nothing (which costs you one dwarf slot).  Hopefully the developer will fix these problems and get the game where it needs to be AI wise.

number of helpful: 3 of 15 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
Early Access Review
								Look, the premise of this game is great. Wonderful idea, charming music and graphics... but this has to be one of the most frustrating gaming experiences i have ever encountered. DO NOT BUY!! Sure, it is early access... but the game claims to be in phase 0.9. That frightens me.The A.I is ATROCIOUS!! 75% of the time... the dwarfs does absolutely everything else then what you want them to do, and there is no way to manually tell them what to do. There is a "control" dwarf command (probably implemented because the developers knew about the broken A.I), but this is just as broken as everything else... all you can do is control the dwarf to the object you want to interact with, and then release control of him and HOPEFULLY he will do what you wanted. Most of the time he will not.The gaming mechanics is ill explained. Want to build a shelter? Sure no problem, you unlock the wooden wall craft pretty early. But how do you build walls? Well, first you build it once... and it becomes a wooden backdrop. Fine.. then you have to figure out that, in order to build a wall you need to build it again on top of the backdrop. But we are not finished yet, no... because that only makes a solid wooden block. The third step is to select the wooden wall craft a third time, and click upon the finished wooden block... which transform it into a proper wall. And NONE OF THIS IS EXPLAINED IN THE GAME!!! Your only hint is "build a shelter!".What´s even more agonizing is that me, (and looking at the forums many others) was plagued with the (one of many) bugs... that makes it so, the GAME DOESN´T RECOGNIZE YOUR SHELTER EVEN THOUGH IT´S CORRECTLY BUILT, UNTIL YOU EXIT THE GAME AND RESTARTS IT!! So, you have to build a shelter, with horrible A.I, obstrusive unexplained building mechanics, and when you have finally guessed your way to a solution, the game doesn´t recognise it (even though, it says you completed the "built" a shelter mission, the shelter is non existent).What is worse is, that a proper shelter is needed in order for you dwarfs to rest. The resting mechanic is just as ill explained as everything else. So for me, the first two hours of gaming my dwarfs didn´t rest... they had zero HP and ran at the smallest enemy, making game progress horrible slow. I didn´t know why my shelter didn´t work, and oh... such a horrible experience.And there is more. The game crashed several times. Bridges flat out doesn´t work. The dwarfs randomly falls through them and starts to drown. At my final gameplay moment, my entire bridge just dissapeared. I could still "de construct it", but it wasn´t there.Uh... such great promise, but such an awful, awful programmed game. DO NOT BUY!!!!!And if this game is in such a state at 0.9? Heck, this feels like a unfinished ALPHA 0.2... i can´t possibly imagine they could fix so many issues for the final build.Stay away!!

												I dont really know what to say about this game, but here's a delicious chocolate cake recipe. :INGREDIENTS FOR CAKE:2 cups white sugar1 3/4 cups all-purpose flour3/4 cup unsweetened cocoa powder1 1/2 teaspoons baking soda1 1/2 teaspoons baking powder1 teaspoon salt2 eggs1 cup milk1/2 cup vegetable oil:INGREDIENTS FOR FROSTING:2 teaspoons vanilla extract1 cup boiling water3/4 cup butter1 1/2 cups unsweetened cocoa powder5 1/3 cups confectioners' sugar2/3 cup milk1 teaspoon vanilla extract:INSTRUCTIONS:1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease and flour two 9 inch cake pans.2. Use the first set of ingredients to make the cake. In a medium bowl, stir together the sugar, flour, cocoa, baking soda, baking powder and salt. Add the eggs, milk, oil and vanilla, mix for 3 minutes with an electric mixer. Stir in the boiling water by hand. Pour evenly into the two prepared pans.3. Bake for 30 to 35 minutes in the preheated oven, until a toothpick inserted comes out clean. Cool for 10 minutes before removing from pans to cool completely.4.To make the frosting, use the second set of ingredients. Cream butter until light and fluffy. Stir in the cocoa and confectioners' sugar alternately with the milk and vanilla. Beat to a spreading consistency.5. Split the layers of cooled cake horizontally, cover the top of each layer with frosting, then stack them onto a serving plate. Frost the outside of the cake.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								When you see the title of the game, "Craft the World" - most people will just think that this game is another attempt to perfect the well known game "Minecraft" - but it isn't. Craft the world is not for everyone though, if you are not a fan of sandbox survival games - you might as well stop reading this review. This game offers so many opportunities when it comes to decision, from - "Would my house stop those pesky ghosts?", "What weapon should I give my Dwarfs?" to "If I don't destroy the goblin encampment now - what's the worst that'll happen?". Trust me - this game is very enjoyable and i highly recommend it to those survival fans out there. Definitely worth the money! =D

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								"Mix of Dungeon Keeper, Minecraft and Dwarf fortress" - Ambitious tag line from the early access steam pageas with all such claims, one must remember that EA killed Bullfrog and so we will never get something close to Dungeon Keeper, only pretenders and charlatansthat said, Craft the world is actually pretty good and is a good way to kill a brainless hour or two, once past the initial undead attacks and you establish a good base with dwarfs armed with clubs after that the game doesn't really pose a challenge it's more of a creative endeavor, where your goal is to create a really cool base while progressing through the tech tree and finding the portal underground so that you can progress to the next world.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								If the price vs it being an early release deters you from what looks otherwise like a fabulous game, don't let it.  This gem of a game has drained near a hundred hours of my time and is still growing. The game is so extremely simple to learn and play, but like any "building" style game just keeps you going and going. And the best part is, the development team is so responsive being early-access that bugs are getting fixed, features are being added, and feedback is being listened to (in a good way, not in a let's change everything because one guy said so way). New updates seem to come out every week or two just getting the game one step closer to being finished. Other's have compared this game to older games they've loved, but I just can't even compare - this is a unique game, or at the very least the first of it's style to get it right.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								Having played "Craft the World" for a mindboggling amount of time for a pre-release game, I feel like I have to add my two cents. Digging, exploring, building, defending and managing are all your responsibility in this (as has been pointed out) Terraria-like indie game. Don't let familiarity with similiar titles sour you to this one. It has its own unique flavor, delightful animations and, most importantly, is utterly addicitive. Patches comes fast and furious so I feel confident this is one title that won't be left to languish. Crucially, I can say that, even were the title to grind to a halt today, I got my monies worth and then some. Even better, I look forward to the finished product and the anticipated improvements to come.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
Early Access Review
								While there remains a few pathing bugs, small features that lack intuitive design--such as a larger warning for design flaws with the dwarven abode and where to fix those flaws--I still find this one enjoyable. The battle features are lacking, with the advancing waves leaving much to be desired. If only there was a premise or reason for the waves constantly attacking and a gradual increase in difficulty that were visually represented, this would complete the experience for me. With that being said however, this is a gamer's vacation away from other games, without waxing enthusiastic on the crafting genre. There have been a few games that cut into this genre that do a very poor job with design, yet this is not one of them. The technical advancement tree is well thought out and makes sense in terms of rhythmic play. The way lighting and terrain plays into the game leaves you patching up every possible angle of defense and lighting every corridor possible to stave off the encroaching threat. I believe this will do well if the developers improve the AI of the dwarves (and enemies) to include line of sight issues with ranged weapons and add diversity to the threats themselves.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
Early Access Review
								Incredible game.  Absolutely incredible.I enjoy this game immensely, and I'm picky when it comes to crafting sandbox games when it comes to holding my attention.  The learning curve is easy, the crafting system is intuitive, the graphics appealing and enjoyable to view for hours on end, and the depth of gameplay is deep.On the surface, it may look like Terraria or Starbound with different graphics.  I can attest to the fact that this is far from the truth.  Craft The World takes the best of multiple games and puts them all into one incredibly fun package, all while adding something new to the genre.  The developers have done a phenomenal job getting this game into great shape, and even though it's still early in development, I had absolutely no issues playing an entire 25 hour campaign mission straight through.  The occasional restart will fix any major game breaking bugs that pop up, and that's about as easy as it comes when you're talking about an early release.While I've got high hopes for some unannounced features, this is and will be a solid game moving into the future.  I'm extra excited for the concept of multiplayer, so fingers crossed we'll see it in the future.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
												I've put in over 30 hours.  I'm not even crafting mithril weapons and armor yet.  Instead, I'm growing wheat to make beer.  The dwarves love beer and consume lots of it.Oh yeah, there is the monster portal that opens every 45 minutes.  Every time I survive, I tell myself I should go to bed.  Next thing I know, there is 7 minutes left until the next portal opens and I've upgraded armor or weapons and think I should try it out...just one more time.The dwarf AI is not great - however, that's part of the charm.  You have to save these guys.  Build signs to deter them or craft doors (and lock them).  I've enjoyed my time in it.  It's fun.  If you like Terraria and/or crafting games, give it a chance.Update:  I'm now over 175 hours into the game.  It's an obsession.  The tech tree is huge - I've built everything and am on the last part of the campaign.  I've learned to hate the ghosts and gargoyles.  They are annoying.  I more than got my money out of this game.  However, I've learned it's not for everyone.  The game can be tedious at times.  You will also get frustrated with the AI - it can make some really poor choices.  You will also hate the damn ghost - I'd like to just turn them off.  I don't see the point.Wish list if there is ever a "part 2":-Upgradable tower defenses.  Yes, we have the archer tower and tesla-thing.  I would like more.-What about adding golems?  I wouldn't mind having some that could haul materials, patrol, and perhaps even do some mining.  Once you start crafting silver armor - the game shifts and requires you to mine lots of metals.  I have been giving orders that take 30 minutes or so - I do something else while they are mining.  This is tedious and gets boring.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												WOW! I mean seriously! WOW!ImpressionThis game is just simply amazing! I bought it while it was on sale, however, I would gladly have payed full price. The game is currently in early access phase. Sometimes, with early access there is definitely some bugs or some issues with the game. This is true at this point. But the issues are minor enough that I really don’t mind a lot. I’m sure they will iron them out and if they don’t, the game is still amazing and I would still pay full price. What is it?	This game has some definite parallels to popular games such as Terraria. That isn’t a bad thing either. The success of Terraria is undeniable. I have played many hours of that game myself. This is NOT a terraria clone however. This has similar features and gameplay models but it is far from the same. In this game you are more of a dwarf god in that you tell them to chop a tree down and they go to work. You don’t have one character to traverse the world with, you control multiple characters to tell what to do and watch the magic. Still want that control of being a character? Don’t worry, they got you covered. You can individually control the dwarfs as well. There are also a lot of great twists on old enemies as well as some spectacular new ones. Did I mention there is also experience and reward as such? This is great since nothings is worse then the same old dwarf with the same old abilities. You can also outfit your cool warriors with armor, weapons, tools, fishing poles, and so much more. The goal is to survive and thrive into a great dwarf community. I have over 5 hours of play time as of now and that’s what I know so far. I’m absolutely amazed at how good this game is.Buy or Fly?	The ultimate question you’re probably asking yourself is, “Should I buy this damn game or not?” Well, if you like boring straightforward cookie cutter games with absolutely predictable gameplay, then don’t buy this game. If you like fun, new and creative ways to play a mix of genres, then this is a MUST BUY! I would absolutely recommend this game. This game is on iPhone and iPad?! Buy or Fly?	Silly question. YES! I bought it on both Steam and my iPhone/iPad already! It’s the same game on both but a slightly different experience. Either one is worth buying but I say buy both!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
Early Access Review
								This game is surprisingly deep (pun semi-intended) and addictive to a fault. The biggest problem with the game is that the tutorial system is nonexistent and one or two aspects of the game are non-intuitive (builiding a shelter) but once you get over the frustration this is an amazingly fun game. I think there's still room to add more depth to the quest system (i.e. the quests basically just ask you to build every item in the tech tree which is something you'd do anyway and not really a separate mission) and the bestiary doesn't seem to work (it's stuck on one page and indicates stats for monsters that seem to become inaccurate over time) but so far this game has a lot going for it.That's the biggest problem I have with this game at its current state, there's no explanation for how the various components actually work and there's a lot of guesswork involved in figuring out how to best use each piece. It would be nice if there was a little explanation, or video of how they all work to clarify things. For example, the cart system isn't totally clear, or how to get mages to use spell potions (they vanish when you try and equip them) or why you can "construct" spells, but gain nothing from it.The in-game analogy is that this game is really deep, but the developers have dug themselves in without building ladders to let people climb down. Players have to fall a lot before they understand what's going on well enough to find the best ways to get in and out.In addition it would be nice if there was a way of directly commanding the dwarves in combat other than taking direct control and forcing an individual dwarf's actions. It would be nice if you could select specific dwarves and tell them where to go together to attack a specific target. There is a rally spell but it only forces them to stand in one spot and doesn't allow much beyond that. For combat it would be good to be able to  move in unison and attack together, the current set up doesn't allow for this and makes fighting large numbers of enemies a tricky circumstance. Being able to assign dwarves to guard specific spots would be good also.A quick note for people who may be confused with how to build a shelter:The game world has two layers, foreground and background including for construction. In order to build a proper wall you must build both the background layer and the foreground layer (i.e. build one space twice if it's empty). In order to build a shelter you must fill the shelter with background walls, the perimiter with background and foreground walls, and have doors/hatches (doors are for lateral, hatches are for vertical) at every intended opening, and you must have a totem somewhere within that space.A second note on construction:I realized this after many, many hours of play (after finishing the first world, in fact) but you can construct dirt/stone/sand directly back into the world and even use it as a building material for your structure. This is incredibly useful knowledge and yet the game doesn't teach you this anywhere, you sort of just have to stumble into it, but bear this in mind as dirt is a lot easier to get ahold  of than the other building materials you have to spend ages collecting resources for in order to create. Plus it's a cheap way to fill in inconvenient dig sites, or construct yourself a real dwarf burrow inside the earth.Overall a great game, and mostly inutitive, but seriously needs further development of the quest system and better explanation of how the game works (tutorials, an in game help system, a wiki, anything is better than the short blurbs in there at the moment.).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
Early Access Review
								Incredible game, it is much more Dwarf Fortress and less Terraria/Dungeon Keeper. Overall the game is one of the best "early access" games I have ever played on Steam. I highly recommend this game, below is my break down of why I like this game.Graphics: Very well done. When you equip gear on your dwarfs, this is reflected in their in game appearance. Everything fits well and just looks awesome. There are tons of little touches like portraits and ornate beds that look stunning. I love Terraria but this game blows Terraria out of the water in this department.Sound: The music is nice, but the game shines in the ambient sound department: war cries, snoring, mumbling, etc...  Gameplay: There is a lot to this game. I mean lots and LOTS of items to craft and things to do. In 10 hours of gameplay I have completed maybe 2/3rds of the crafting quests. The game has a bit of a tough start, but once you get the hang of defense it is fairly simple to set up your fort. The difficulty increasing smoothly and I never felt that it got "too easy" at any point.UI: Pretty simple once you get the hang of it. You have an inventory and a hot key bar. Crafting is done in box type thng like Minecraft/TerreriaFun: Very addicting, there is always more stuff to build, places to explore, hordes to fight off.Bugs: There really aren't many. Occasionally my dwarfs forget what bed they own, but exiting the game seems to fix it. The bad stuff: My only real negative is that I know nothing about the developer, I think they are Russian and they have made an Android app game... but beyond that I really would like to know what their plans are. This game came out of no where, but it is really so well done and refined.That being said this game is a blast. Even in its current state there is a lot of fun to be had. This game has all the potential a blockbuster like Terraria

								I have been playing this game for awhile now, and anyone that thinks it is a Minecraft or Terraria clone is wrong on many levels.  Yes you build dwellings and fight off evil nasties, but in this game you are deeling with Drawfs.  The problem being is that at the begining they are really stupid.  Also you have to learn items in your crafting tree one at a time to complete other items.  What I mean is that I had to create several items before I could make a door for my dwelling.  So yes there are plenty of differences.  But even thou it can be fustrating, I am rating this game 8 out of 10.  It is only in Beta form right now and you can really play and enjoy it.  So if your looking for a game you can build, dig and fight, this is your game!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
Early Access Review
								I bought this during one of the flash sales. The moment I eyeballed it, I knew it was a game I wanted to play. I like the concepts (and played) of Minecraft, Terraria, and Dwarf Fortress have, and generally like the game that take these concepts and put it into a gamel ike this. The ability to control a team of dwarves, construct a fortress, and survive in a world is a great thing. Minecraft and Terraria, while fun in their own merits, get stale after a time. Letting your creativity flow to create cool things in those games are pretty sweet, but I need more to it than being able to create things of fancy. That's why I like Dwarf Fortress. You create a fortress for dwarves, make them happy, and create a fort that suits them (though most who play DF consider efficiency high on the list more than aesthetics). And in thae game, you have to deal with all sorts of dangers risking your entire fort. That's what I like. I like the idea of creating this "fortress" with all sorts of perils come at you and try to wreck your day. This game is tamer in that resepct, than Dwarf Fortress, but it shows a lot of promise. It has some issues at the moment of this writing, but it was expected for being early access. There are some noticeable bugs, and feels like there's more left to add (obviously). However, I think it's on the right track to its potential. For those who don't buy into "early access", I'd say keep an eye on it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
Early Access Review
								A Superb Example of 2D RPG Sandbox Survival!As the developer says, If you like games such as Terraria, Dwarf Fortress, and Dungeon Keeper, then you are going to love this game. It is very well polished even in it's early access form. It has excellent graphics, sounds, and game play.Lots of collectible resources and a simple crafting system make crafting items a breeze, and the armor and weapons for your dwarves are well balanced. You truely feel you have accomplished something when you take the time to outfit your motley crew with the latest item upgrades, allowing them to take on larger hordes of enemies, but not making them invincible.As with any game of this nature, it will likely take you a couple play throughs to get the hang of things. Challenging enough to keep you playing for hours on end, while still giving you helpful queues along the way to aid you in progressing. You never feel lost trying to figure out what you should do next, but you also never feel like the game is making decisions for you. The only issue I ran into was while trying to get my dwarves' house secure enough that they would sleep. I had built the house, and placed beds, but the game didn't seem to recognize the house was secure. (A secure home is completely sealed with or without a door, and contains a Totem and a bed for each of your dwarves). A quick internet search suggested that I exit the game and restart. After doing this, the game recognized my house was secure and I never had trouble from then on. I have played Craft the World for 10 hours so far, and have not fully explored or conquered the first small world. I am sure I will log some serious time on this game. I highly recommend this game!

Early Access Review
								Firstly i fully disagree with people comparing this game to Terraria, Starbound or even Minecraft. This game is nothing like any of those games. This game is more of a strategy based game you know you are going to be attack so do the best to set up defences while you mine and gather resources. The graphics for this game are amazing for the type of game it is. I specially like the fact that when i change the Dwarfs armour it reflects in the game that they now have different armour.Crafting in this game is amazing the fact this game is still in early access and has this much crafting is really amazing. I can’t wait to see what the developer adds to this game in the next updates (hopefully new larger maps)As for game play i have been playing this game a lot in fact 30 + hours and i still am loving this game completely so much still to do. There are a few things i would like to see fixed like when you click on a mob to kill and accidently remove your dam wall bit of a pain but other than that this game caters for all aspects of gamers from beginner to someone after a challenge If you’re undecided about this game i encourage you to give it a try, hell it’s the price of 3 maybe 4 coffees in most countries Lastly i must admit i purchased this game as a joke game to play when i was really bored, however after playing this game it is currently the game i play the most was completely surprised when i purchased it and that night and 6 hours later looked at the clock and wow 3am had passed.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								I have been enjoying this game along with my younger brother and sister. A very addictive and relaxing game as well as just cute and fun. I'll put my pros and cons here to sum up some of the best and worst aspects as of now.Pros: Fun detailed 2D graphics style         Easy to understand crafting interface.         Lots of variety in creatures as well as materials.         A leveling system which grants more and more Dwarves as you go.         A sense of accomplishment as you dig further down and build higher up.         Dwarves have a class assigned to them when they spawn in.Cons: Some pathfinding issues but they are getting better.          Dwarves don't build or dig in the order you give them - As if they had a mind of their own          The music is nice but lacking in variety.          And my main problem with this game, while not a game ruiner by any means, is the translation problems. All in all I will give this game a 9/10 because the pros heavily outweigh the cons and the team working on this has obviously put a lot of love into this gem.Hope this helps someone decide whether or not to buy the game.

content:
Posted: April 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								I like games like Keflings, Terraria, and Minecraft. I picked it up because it looked right up my alley. I gave it a try and suddenly it was 8 hours later... Its very much one of those "just one more thing" games. I really enjoy having the dwarves do my dirty work and just managing everything rather than doing it all myself like in other games. The AI seems pretty good. There are a lot of things to make, and you're left to build whatever you want with them. I liked the variety of enemies, and the occasional waves of attacks to keep you focused. There's really a lot in the game as it stands now.In starting you are kind of left to your own devices to figure things out. The tech tree is pretty clear and there is a help section in the book with the basics, but the main thing I just totally didn't get on my own until at least a couple hours in was how to build a house- ie a secure shelter. My dwarves were getting beat up and wouldn't eat or sleep. I thought you had to build the wood walls etc that you don't unlock till later, so I was frantically trying to get that far in the tree, and even then I had no idea how to actually make walls on top of the background. My friend had to eventually show me.Seeing as this game isn't even done yet, I can't wait to see what more they add!

content:
Posted: May 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a good and engaging game. It has a good overall theme and artwork. The game play is fairly straight-forward as well. Dig, Defend, and build. Rinse and Repeat and the defending gets more difficult the longer the campaign goes on. It's a great in sandbox mode for just building/crafting fun. Campaign mode can be fun and a bit challenging. It's still early access so it's hard to be to critical for a game that hasn't declared itself mostly done.This game suffers a bit of strangeness when it comes to the UI and ease of use when playing on a computer. Though they do make sense if this game ever went to a tablet like an iPad or possibly a console? A few things I do not care for but are not real deal breakers for me* The strength of monsters seems difficult to gauge. Knowing if you can kill a monster is not an easy question to answer. Just hope they don't kill your dwarves* Monster noises particularly the goblins get a bit excessive and repetitive i makes me cringe.* The game also fails to really explain the use of spells and mana usage. * I find it strange when it comes to AI with regards to priorities of tasks. I click on things and getting them to do it seems hard or impossible sometimes* There is a bit of unnecesary crafting of things i never wanted to use but crafted in order to advanced my crafting skills to make the things I really wanted to. For example crafting 20 gargoyle statues that have no effect other than vanity seems silly so i can make something else worthwhile

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
Early Access Review
								This game is surprisingly deep (pun semi-intended) and addictive to a fault. The biggest problem with the game is that the tutorial system is nonexistent and one or two aspects of the game are non-intuitive (builiding a shelter) but once you get over the frustration this is an amazingly fun game. I think there's still room to add more depth to the quest system (i.e. the quests basically just ask you to build every item in the tech tree which is something you'd do anyway and not really a separate mission) and the bestiary doesn't seem to work (it's stuck on one page and indicates stats for monsters that seem to become inaccurate over time) but so far this game has a lot going for it.That's the biggest problem I have with this game at its current state, there's no explanation for how the various components actually work and there's a lot of guesswork involved in figuring out how to best use each piece. It would be nice if there was a little explanation, or video of how they all work to clarify things. For example, the cart system isn't totally clear, or how to get mages to use spell potions (they vanish when you try and equip them) or why you can "construct" spells, but gain nothing from it.The in-game analogy is that this game is really deep, but the developers have dug themselves in without building ladders to let people climb down. Players have to fall a lot before they understand what's going on well enough to find the best ways to get in and out.In addition it would be nice if there was a way of directly commanding the dwarves in combat other than taking direct control and forcing an individual dwarf's actions. It would be nice if you could select specific dwarves and tell them where to go together to attack a specific target. There is a rally spell but it only forces them to stand in one spot and doesn't allow much beyond that. For combat it would be good to be able to  move in unison and attack together, the current set up doesn't allow for this and makes fighting large numbers of enemies a tricky circumstance. Being able to assign dwarves to guard specific spots would be good also.A quick note for people who may be confused with how to build a shelter:The game world has two layers, foreground and background including for construction. In order to build a proper wall you must build both the background layer and the foreground layer (i.e. build one space twice if it's empty). In order to build a shelter you must fill the shelter with background walls, the perimiter with background and foreground walls, and have doors/hatches (doors are for lateral, hatches are for vertical) at every intended opening, and you must have a totem somewhere within that space.A second note on construction:I realized this after many, many hours of play (after finishing the first world, in fact) but you can construct dirt/stone/sand directly back into the world and even use it as a building material for your structure. This is incredibly useful knowledge and yet the game doesn't teach you this anywhere, you sort of just have to stumble into it, but bear this in mind as dirt is a lot easier to get ahold  of than the other building materials you have to spend ages collecting resources for in order to create. Plus it's a cheap way to fill in inconvenient dig sites, or construct yourself a real dwarf burrow inside the earth.Overall a great game, and mostly inutitive, but seriously needs further development of the quest system and better explanation of how the game works (tutorials, an in game help system, a wiki, anything is better than the short blurbs in there at the moment.).

content:

Early Access Review
								If the price vs it being an early release deters you from what looks otherwise like a fabulous game, don't let it.  This gem of a game has drained near a hundred hours of my time and is still growing. The game is so extremely simple to learn and play, but like any "building" style game just keeps you going and going. And the best part is, the development team is so responsive being early-access that bugs are getting fixed, features are being added, and feedback is being listened to (in a good way, not in a let's change everything because one guy said so way). New updates seem to come out every week or two just getting the game one step closer to being finished. Other's have compared this game to older games they've loved, but I just can't even compare - this is a unique game, or at the very least the first of it's style to get it right.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								I really like this game! I read the negative reviews first and found one person who was complaining there was not enough fighting. Please do not turn this into another defense game, there are plenty of those in the world. As the name is Craft The World enemy interaction ought to be secondary to crafting. So I bought it and found that crafting/resource collection is the primary focus. I am excited that this is on Mac as well surprising for an early release there are not that many. I started in Sandbox mode and liked that I didn't have to play through craft tree to get that version. I did struggle for a few hours on the Totem and house building, not sure if that was to add to difficulty or if there will be more guidance later on. As far as an early release goes this is quite built out. You will be learning through trial and error to figure the game out but I enjoyed the challenge. One thing I struggled with was the shop. The items pop out and they are small so I didn't see them and thought that part may not be complete yet but they do spawn in front and have to be collected like other resources. I know the shadow is intentional but the light spell dosen't go far enough would be nice to get 5 or so blocks to plan out your dig. However, you can still re-add any of the collected resources back if you want. I am surprised at the graphics, though simple they are much better than many of the crafting games. I think its just right not to much not to little. There are difficulty levels so you can select the level of challenge. I really like that you can craft something without having the pattern yet so the really critical crafts you can remember the sequence to help you at the beginning. I can't wait to see what is still to come!

content:
Posted: October 12, 2015
												Think "Dwarf Fortress/Minecraft/Terraria/SimTower" all molded into one. Now you're digging it!At first glance I hoped this would be a good game, boy was I surprised when I found myself completly obsessed with playing Craft the World. I missed work, I didn't eat, I just played and played till I finally finished everything the game had to offer, which at the time was only one level..Now we find ourselves 1 year down the road and I decided to check in with my past adiction. I felt as though it was calling me with a whisper "Updates" "Updates" it said softly and I was none the wiser, I laucnhed the game and found not only another level but to my surprise I found 3. As if I thought that was enough the final underground level was astounding design! That is not to say the other two where not great too, but yet again I found myself completly adicted.To explain bluntly, each level is an entire game. When you start the level you are looking at an entire 15-30 hours of gameplay which for a person like me is perfect. You could lose everything in an instant and for a game that takes so long to finish, that can be a problem, but if everything goes according to plan then you finally start to feel the reward.I wouldn't not recommend this game to anyone.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 9, 2015
												I have played this game quite a bit, from early access to what we've got now. Of course the worst part of this game is the AI. Pathfinding is atrocious and highly annoying. I ended up cheating the speed of the dwarves (nothing too crazy just enough to make pathfinding a non-issue).Where the game falls short (other than pathfinding) is the fact that each world you have to start over from scratch. You just spent 20-30 hours on a level and now you've got to start allll over again. I have never played two levels in a row because it's just no longer fun. It will take a few months before I want to start over again.The technology tree is messed up, definitely. There are things that should be in the beginning and things that should not affect technology. All deco stuff needs to have its own designated tree. I should not have to make windows so I can make better doors or better pickaxes.Enough of the rant, this game is fun. Frustrating at times, but which game isn't? It lacks constant replayability but coming back to the game every few months seems to work for me.Pros:-Addictive-Being able to control a dwarf and building quickly without needing to go back to the stockpile.-The graphics are nice.-Devs update the game.-Lots to do, no time to do it.-I can't stress enough that this game is actually fun.Cons:-AI is terrible,-Technology tree could use some tweaking. End game items are only used if you decide not to go on to the next level (absolutely no goal left, so no reason to keep playing).-Restart after level advance.-Max fast forward is 2x (at least they added a fast forward).-Animals are too scarce in the beginning and the farm isn't available till about halfway and by that time the animals respawn at a nice rate and you can move around the map with ease so farm is useless.-2 height reach is extremely annoying. 3 or 4 should be standard with a way to make this a setting. Many times you are left with no choice but to use many ladders which take a long time. Scaffolding is available but at a decent time away from game start.This game has got lots of cons but that doesn't mean that I don't enjoy it. If these issues were fixed I'd probably play this non-stop. If you think the cons are an issue get this game on sale, don't miss out.

Especially with the structure of the tech tree. There are many techs where i think: "Why is it there? And not there?" for example armor. New armor comes very late, but in late game, they all come nearly at once. Why? Why do i unlock Iron Armor, to unlock Silver Armor as soon as i crafted some Iron Armor? Only to unlock Gold Armor, as soon as i crafted some Silver Armor.Crap.Same with beds. I unlock beds Tier 2, only to unlock allready Tier 3 before i even crafted enough Tier 2 beds for my dwarves. And thats really annoying. When i need stuff, i don't get it. And when i get it, i don't need it anymore because i allready unlock better one before i finish crafting.And the other thing i don't like is the late game of each level. It's dumb digging for Portal parts. And it gets even worse with every level since the map increases in size. It's okay to dig for real progress, to get new and different ores for better equipment. But it's horrible annoying if you need to dig down the whole map only to find those portal parts when you allready have everything you need. (except the portal parts, of course.)So yeah, i like the gameplay, but tech trees and late game content really needs a change.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												This game has a solid foundation, but has several major design flaws. Since the game already has a lot of positive reviews, I'll focus on why mine is negative.First off, it's extremely slow paced. It requires a lot of micro management, so you can't just set orders and go do something else. But it moves so slowly that you'll be sitting doing nothing for a minute or two after assigning new orders. Set some blocks to mine, trees to cut down, animals to hunt, then open portals near those places. Now wait 2 minutes while your dwarves finish those tasks. Then repeat. In order to play at an engaging speed, I actually used an external program to run the game at triple speed, which improved the game significantly.Second is the crafting "tree". All items, weapons, equipment, decoration, supplies, etc are bunched into groups of 4-5 items. In order to unlock a new group of items, you have to craft a certain number of items from the group (or two) that lead up to it. Crafting a lot of only one item from that group has diminishing returns, so it is best to craft 2-3 of each item in the group. The problem is, it isn't laid out in a tree. The next tier of armor might have furniture and glassware as prerequisites (as an example, I don't remember exactly). But each of THOSE requires 1-2 other groups first. So you can't rush to the items you want: you have to make EVERY ITEM IN THE GAME a few times to progress. This just compounds the first problem, slowing down the game. Even though you could easily just dig down and get mithril to make the best gear in the game, you can't actually craft those items until you've made every single other item in the game several times over. Imagine if in Minecraft, even though you can easily dig down and find diamonds in 10 minutes, you couldn't actually make diamond gear until you've spent 10 hours gathering materials and crafting every other in the game 20 times. Or if in Civilazation, there were no tech trees and you just had to research every single technology, in the same order, every game. That's what it feels like. There's no choice. It gets boring and tedious after the first time. Third is the lack of real progression from level to level in the campaign. There are four "worlds" in the campaign. Beat one, go to the next one. Here's the problem: each world only has a few new items to make. You play world one, get your dwarves decked out in the best gold and mithril gear, and then move on to world two... and you're back collecting sticks and leaves. World two lets you build four "ice" versions of other items, which are only better in that using ice doesn't waste the more valuable resources. Then you go through the whole crafting tree, taking forever to get enough resources to get up to gold and mithril again, so you can go on to world three and start all over again. World four finally adds some new weapons, which is nice, but they aren't a huge improvement on the same weapons you've been using since world one. It just doesn't feel like you're progressing. Normally in a campaign, when you move on to the next world you get access to stronger gear and the like. But in Craft the World, you work through the exact same progression over and over.My overall conclusion is that the game has potential but is poorly designed. A major overhaul could make it really good. Increasing dwarf movement speed so you don't have to micromanage portals for transportation would be amazing. Sorting the tech tree by item type would be a big help. Iron armor -> silver armor -> gold armor, instead of iron armor -> glassware -> fabric dying -> whatever -> silver armor or whatever the progression is. This would let you focus on what you want/need at the moment, instead of wasting your time making items you don't need first. When I need better armor so my dwarves can survive the next invasion, I don't want to have to make a ton of armoires first. The last major change would be changes to the scope of the campaign worlds. World one should be shorter, with iron as the only available metal, and weaker guardians that only require that iron gear to beat. Then world two is slightly larger, with silver added and guardians that require silver to beat. This way, the player actually feels a sense of progression from world to world. As is, it's just painful and quite frankly STUPID to go from mithril right back to wood, and then have to work back up to mithril. Also, don't make me unlock all the crap again in world two, three, four. It's a 100-200 hour game, with only 10-20 hours worth of content.Of course, for a lot of people it isn't just a game where you rush to beat the campaign. Like Minecraft, it's about building your vision of the perfect home. But in Minecraft, when you have a new vision you start a new world and can quickly have everything you need to start building again, but in Craft the World the tech system means that if you start a new world, it'll be at least 10 hours before you start to see your vision take shape.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												I'm going to review this game with the premise that it one of a few games that could be categorized as Dwarf Fortress like, and will refer to DF throughout the review. The game has some major flaws, but overall it's a great game and is well worth the price. I'll start with the negatives. The AI is not great. The dwarves have a strange way of prioritizing what needs done, so you can't queue up too many task at once, or it will take forever for the important ones to get finished. They also path terribly sometimes, ignoring nearby warp portals if was built after they decided to go somewhere. They will also walk into a hole another dwarf is about to fill to pick up dirt, and will just stand there deciding what to do next, rather than realize they will be trapped. Also wood is far too important for building for not being able to reliable plant it yourself. You end up using the portal spell to send your dwarves out onto the fringe of the world for a few trees all the time. The tech tree is also very poorly implemented. The order in which the dwarves research things is very strange, with seemingly easy things towards the end of the tree and hard things at the beginning. It also forces you to make countless items you'll never use, simply to advance the tree. Combat can also seem kinda clunky, as dwarves will sometimes waltz away from a monster wave simply because none of the monsters are marked for combat. The lack of a profession system is also very irritating. In DF and many DF like games, you assign your dwarves/gnomes/goblins/etc a job, and they perform that job. Such as smith, miner, logger, etc. In this game all dwarves do everything. There is a skill system (dwarves gain up to 3 skills in things such as logging, swimming, archery, etc), and I've read that a job is done by the dwarf with the highest skill in that task, who is currently not doing anything. While I'm not sure if this system even works, it is a bad idea to begin with. The game can also begin to be repetitive. At 21.6 hours I've beat the first world and have moved onto the second world. You simply begin back at square one, with one dwarf and an empty tech tree. The only difference is that the world is harder. I can easily see how other people with more hours and who have gotten to further worlds say that by world 5 the game is boring. Now to the good. The side view 2D is an interesting perspective, and fresh from many of the other top down view DF like games, or any city builders in general. The fortress defense mechanic is very fun. Although the nightly skeleton/zombie hordes do not get any more challenging, the hourly monster raids do start to get harder. This is until all your dwarves are equipped with mithril weapons/armor, at which point the game becomes fairly easy again. The tech tree, while overall being badly implemented, can do a good job at driving you forward to research new items. There are several types of metal to work with, which leads to a nice flow of upgrading your weapons. There are also several types of walls/roofs (once you finally research them), so you can make cool looking forts. Although the game does discourage making individual bedrooms (by keeping interior doors until well into the tech tree) and this does detract from making interesting looking forts. Once you also get farming (well into the tech tree, this is another negative) you can make interesting looking fortresses with attached underground farms. This is always one of my most fun parts of DF like games. The spells are nice too, and make you feel much more involved than many DF like games. Dwarves getting tired of eating certain food too often, forcing you to take advantage of the different types of food available. While I love Gnomoria, I hate knowing I can just grow wheat and my gnomes will never get tired of eating wheat bread and drinking wheat beer (in fact spamming wheat in it is to your advantage). Overall, the thrill of the first 15-30 hours is great. You want to explore just one more tunnel before you go to sleep, and the portal spell makes exploring the fringes of the world much more accessible. If you don't mind spending 20 dollars on a great 30 hours, and then (from what I've heard) an "eh" another 20 hours before the game is just too repetitive, then this is a great game for you. If you are a fan of a DF and are looking for something less intense and requires less time and energy, this game is also great for you (or if you are too scared to jump straight into DF but want to play a fortress builder).
