content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
												This sort of game never really appealled to me before; however, it a gem of a game that I have thoroughy enjoyed for a very long playtime. Initially there is a steep learning curve for getting started, but the charming and progressive gameplay really draws you in. The premise of the game is simple, build a home for your dwarfs and get them to delve deep into the earth to discover rare materials needed to strengthen the dwarfs home and their own gear. Each world requires you to survive and then  find the portal on to the next world. This can take 10-15 hours of playtime per level and the final world is very challenging, with enough variety to keep the tech tree engaging.  For the price, this game is a bargain, especially if I compare the played time I have on lots of other expensive games that cost far far more. Hopefully the developers will continue to add new worlds and techs to this very charming and addictive game!

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												Craft the World is a fun Minecraft/Terraia style game, held back by an extremely long and boring technology tree and a severe lack of enemies.Unlike most crafting games, progressing from one tier of items to the next does not just require building the correct crafting table and gather enough resources, it also requires you to have advanced the tree by building tons of items at the prior level.Want to build iron swords? Oops, gotta build 5 more wooden sheilds first.Trying to bake a cake for your hungry dwarves? Well, I hope you caught a bunch of fish first, to advance up,Found a vein of platinum you want to craft? Sorry, your dwarves need to master bed & lightbulb construction before they'll even try to make a new set of armor.Combat content (enemy types) run out far too quickly as well.After surviving the nightly zombie raids, and killing the local goblin camp (with your level 1 wooden swords), there's nothing left to fight except god-tier golems in hidden chambers deep underground.  And if you want to fight them? Well, prepare to spend hours mining out every level of the  In the end, Craft the World is a very accurate title. By the end of the game, you'll have mined the entire world, and converted it into a procession of increasingly meaningless cosmetic items, on a quest to advance the technology tree far enough to get some decent combat equipment for your dwarves.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												This game is right up my alley.  It's a blend of Terraria with the autonomous command-driven functionality of dwarf fortress.  It's an interesting amalgam of the two games, though not nearly in-depth and strategic as DF, and lacking the insane quantity of content of Terraria.  If the developer maintains a level of involvement half that of the Terraria dev, this game has huge potential.  As it stands right now, early game discovery is a superb experience.  Mid-game, you focus on building yourself up and reaching higher tech levels.  I haven't made it to end-game content yet, but I hear it's lacking.Bottom line, do I recommend it?  Hellz yeah.  And $10 is an excellent price point for this game.  In hindsight I would have purchased it at full price, but I had no idea it would be this good.

												I am in love with this game, the sort of game you can leave for a week and just pick up where you left off.... And you will have to! There is no playing a single level in one sitting (unless I'm really bad at this game)...I am STILL on level 2 and have clocked 50 hours!Basically you are micro managing  a small population of dwarves - you order them to cut trees, mine ore, kill enemies etc... All while building a house with good comfort so that dwarves sleep well and gain health back faster. Every 45 minutes you get a wave of monsters which gets harder and more portals will start opening. So it's a micro managing - tower defence - creativity - mining game!!! You can also make equipement and kit out each dwarf. It is in my top five games.My only cons are that Dwarves hang around an awful lot even if you have ordered them to do things, sometimes its just faster to control one manually. I don't like how they drop all of their items to ALL go and attack a snail if you accidently click on it and I also get infuriated when a dwarf decides to take the long and treacherous route home instead of the portal! BUT seriously, those are just irks lol! LOVE this game, worth every penny. The app is pretty good too but it's a couple of updates behind.

												Craft The World is a nice-looking 2D dwarf-colony-gestion game. From the top you should know it gets repetitive as the campaign is limited to a few maps and the only progression is towards crafting items to unlock the next technology, and beat bosses to reach the next level. However:-It's really addictive: you'll dig down through time or your wife's labor.-Pathfinding and AI may seem dumb but it's your job to take control and direct your dwarves from time to time. You can play with minimal investment if you wish.-You design your dwarves's home/castle/dungeon/fortress while trying to optimize paths and comfort.-The map is living, with hordes of ennemies appearing and regular mob spawning. Defend yourself !-Has a smell of Terraria, with an army of automated dwarves !-You can play it with one hand on the mouse and a newborn in the other arm.I love it.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												It's a funny game that makes a lot of fun. My first Review was positive. I enjoy the graphics very much, and even when the game is still in early access, it is nearly coomplete und absolute playable.So why negative rating?I don't agree with the dev's way of balancing. Especially with the structure of the tech tree. There are many techs where i think: "Why is it there? And not there?" for example armor. New armor comes very late, but in late game, they all come nearly at once. Why? Why do i unlock Iron Armor, to unlock Silver Armor as soon as i crafted some Iron Armor? Only to unlock Gold Armor, as soon as i crafted some Silver Armor.Crap.Same with beds. I unlock beds Tier 2, only to unlock allready Tier 3 before i even crafted enough Tier 2 beds for my dwarves. And thats really annoying. When i need stuff, i don't get it. And when i get it, i don't need it anymore because i allready unlock better one before i finish crafting.And the other thing i don't like is the late game of each level. It's dumb digging for Portal parts. And it gets even worse with every level since the map increases in size. It's okay to dig for real progress, to get new and different ores for better equipment. But it's horrible annoying if you need to dig down the whole map only to find those portal parts when you allready have everything you need. (except the portal parts, of course.)So yeah, i like the gameplay, but tech trees and late game content really needs a change.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
Early Access Review
								This game is surprisingly deep (pun semi-intended) and addictive to a fault. The biggest problem with the game is that the tutorial system is nonexistent and one or two aspects of the game are non-intuitive (builiding a shelter) but once you get over the frustration this is an amazingly fun game. I think there's still room to add more depth to the quest system (i.e. the quests basically just ask you to build every item in the tech tree which is something you'd do anyway and not really a separate mission) and the bestiary doesn't seem to work (it's stuck on one page and indicates stats for monsters that seem to become inaccurate over time) but so far this game has a lot going for it.That's the biggest problem I have with this game at its current state, there's no explanation for how the various components actually work and there's a lot of guesswork involved in figuring out how to best use each piece. It would be nice if there was a little explanation, or video of how they all work to clarify things. For example, the cart system isn't totally clear, or how to get mages to use spell potions (they vanish when you try and equip them) or why you can "construct" spells, but gain nothing from it.The in-game analogy is that this game is really deep, but the developers have dug themselves in without building ladders to let people climb down. Players have to fall a lot before they understand what's going on well enough to find the best ways to get in and out.In addition it would be nice if there was a way of directly commanding the dwarves in combat other than taking direct control and forcing an individual dwarf's actions. It would be nice if you could select specific dwarves and tell them where to go together to attack a specific target. There is a rally spell but it only forces them to stand in one spot and doesn't allow much beyond that. For combat it would be good to be able to  move in unison and attack together, the current set up doesn't allow for this and makes fighting large numbers of enemies a tricky circumstance. Being able to assign dwarves to guard specific spots would be good also.A quick note for people who may be confused with how to build a shelter:The game world has two layers, foreground and background including for construction. In order to build a proper wall you must build both the background layer and the foreground layer (i.e. build one space twice if it's empty). In order to build a shelter you must fill the shelter with background walls, the perimiter with background and foreground walls, and have doors/hatches (doors are for lateral, hatches are for vertical) at every intended opening, and you must have a totem somewhere within that space.A second note on construction:I realized this after many, many hours of play (after finishing the first world, in fact) but you can construct dirt/stone/sand directly back into the world and even use it as a building material for your structure. This is incredibly useful knowledge and yet the game doesn't teach you this anywhere, you sort of just have to stumble into it, but bear this in mind as dirt is a lot easier to get ahold  of than the other building materials you have to spend ages collecting resources for in order to create. Plus it's a cheap way to fill in inconvenient dig sites, or construct yourself a real dwarf burrow inside the earth.Overall a great game, and mostly inutitive, but seriously needs further development of the quest system and better explanation of how the game works (tutorials, an in game help system, a wiki, anything is better than the short blurbs in there at the moment.).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
Early Access Review
								I didn't expected this game to be so fun and deep.Now I'm playing it over Starbound. Micro manage your guys when you want it or just click here and there from time to time to relax. There are a few fight tactics to try, and some customisation (skills and gears) for every dwarf of your tribe.There are a few pathfinding/AI issues, but as you can take control of any character from your group, there's always a workaround to issues. Some gameplay parts are also a bit hard to get at first (shelters, elevators, trains) but once you have failed once or googled it, you get the point.The main feature I'd love to see in future patches is an express mode (like time goes x2 or x4 until you get attacked, so the mining/sleeping process is faster).

Early Access Review
								This game is a mixture between Terraria, Gnomoria and Stronghold.Build your own fortress, dig for treasures, gather resources, fight off waves of monsters, do research, equip your dwarves.What I enjoyed most is the fact that this game has it's emphasis on defending vs monsters which always keeps you on your toe. Currently as it is, time always plays an important roleThe classic sandbox approach where you just build and mire is better left for Minecraft and maybe even Terraria, despite the graphics being one of the best one's for this genre so far.I recommend reading some guides first before jumping straight into the game since certain mechanics, i.e. how to build a proper shelter or how to use town portals are not necessarily intuitive yet.

Early Access Review
								All in all, this is a very very good game considering it is still curently only in early access! I havent yet encountered any bugs to my surprise and this game certainly has a lot of potential to be expanded upon, not that there isnt already plenty there for the time being!The only VERY minor problem I have with this game is the difficulty, in that as you progress through the game, it doesn't seem to get much harder as you develop, to the point where even on a game with the difficulty set to nightmare, I am having very little trouble with monsters including the large waves that appear every so often once you reach roughly about the 2 hour mark. The other thing I feel that woild make a good improvement would be the ability to switch at somepoint from a standard game to a permant death game, and then be unable to reverse, as following my above comment, it is quite easy to have a dwarf die in the early stages of the game, but once you reach the stage where you have a base up and running with multiple dwarves, the game does become easier, and I think this may reintroduce some of the challange back into the game at a later stage.However as I said these are very minor points, and all in all a very fun game that has plenty of content and is really promising. I highly recommend this game!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
Early Access Review
								Craft The World is a lot 'deeper' than I thought, pun intended. I have been playing this a lot over the last few days, and it has been very enjoyable and pulls me back. The crafting tree is huge, so I haven't made it through to the end yet. My play style is more of the build and explore type, so I have not rushed to the end yet. In fact, due to loading onto my laptop and desktop both, I've been playing two different campaigns, and enjoying both. I hope that the alternate world/terrain types open up more replayability. But I still have lots of playability left to go.The closest comparison that comes to mind is Gnomoria, though graphically, it is like comparing the original DOS XCOM to the latest 3D versions.It is an 'early access' game, so I am not certain what changes might be in store. Obviously, new content is still being added, such as the new Snow world and the Yeti boss. At this stage, I do wish that it was possible to actually 'lose', but it appears that it is impossible to be wiped out entirely. There are some bugs that get revealed in edge-case scenarios, and this may be why, on one occasion, my last dwarf did not die. He kind of bugged at zero health, and I was able to recover him and un-bug him, and the game continued as new dwarfs joined him to rebuild.It's artwork is lush and beautiful, the sound effects are very good, the enemies are tough in the beginning, though once you get better equipment, the surface enemies are 'easy'. However, there are more enemies waiting for the dwarves in the depths. I can hear their drums calling to me now.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
Early Access Review
								I bought this during one of the flash sales. The moment I eyeballed it, I knew it was a game I wanted to play. I like the concepts (and played) of Minecraft, Terraria, and Dwarf Fortress have, and generally like the game that take these concepts and put it into a gamel ike this. The ability to control a team of dwarves, construct a fortress, and survive in a world is a great thing. Minecraft and Terraria, while fun in their own merits, get stale after a time. Letting your creativity flow to create cool things in those games are pretty sweet, but I need more to it than being able to create things of fancy. That's why I like Dwarf Fortress. You create a fortress for dwarves, make them happy, and create a fort that suits them (though most who play DF consider efficiency high on the list more than aesthetics). And in thae game, you have to deal with all sorts of dangers risking your entire fort. That's what I like. I like the idea of creating this "fortress" with all sorts of perils come at you and try to wreck your day. This game is tamer in that resepct, than Dwarf Fortress, but it shows a lot of promise. It has some issues at the moment of this writing, but it was expected for being early access. There are some noticeable bugs, and feels like there's more left to add (obviously). However, I think it's on the right track to its potential. For those who don't buy into "early access", I'd say keep an eye on it.

content:

												I'm totally new to the concept of crafting games and 12 hrs in, I'm loving it. The tutorial (missing in other things I've tried and given up on) was just right to get me going on how the concept works.  I love how the night brings in monsters to combat - but not so severe as you die on night one! I can feel myself getting better and better at crafting the right tools and arming my little guys ready for the onslaught  (love the countdown to the hoard of nasties). Sometimes my little guys ddon't go the way I want and manual control is a bit tedious - but to be able to control my whole game just with a single point and click device means I can keep 3 limbs under a winter blanket and play whilst snuggled up. As a starter game this has been great and I can see how there is potential to up my skill and get more out of the game as an advancing player. Nothing negative to say about it really - can't wait to see what the future updates bring.

												This game is just simple fun.  It feels like terraria and lemmings had a baby.  There are definetly some areas that need improvement.  When crafting items it kinda sucks having to drag each item into its respective slot.  When equipping one of the Dwarves you can simply double click on an item and it will equip in the proper slot.  But when crafting you are stuck drag and dropping.  Another bit of annoyance comes in when your Dwarves simply don't listen to your orders.  Either you'll get stuck waiting for one of them to craft some items you've queued, or for them to attack a baddie you've marked or other such nonsense.  Another point of annoyance I have had is the idea height of a room is 3 tiles yet Dwarves can only reach 2.  The only way to get to the 3rd is to build scaffolding/ladders or to manually control one of them which gives you access to the 3rd tile.However this is a great game full of fun and enjoyment.  I highly recommend this to anyone that likes this style of game in spite of some of the shortcommings.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												The game is fine. It's not something I've really regretted buying. I just wish that the game had a bit more variety to it. Every level is a case of doing exactly the same thing as you did on the previous level. While the incidental difficulty of the maps becomes greater (i.e. monsters are more difficult), I found it easier to mine necessary resources at later levels. I only just had enough mithril on my first map to finish the game, and with just enough to make a single mithril helmet and sword - not enough for 12 dwarves. If it weren't for the christmas easter egg equipment, I probably wouldn't have been able to survive the portal guardians.The game is also super slow. Like Civ 3 slow. It took me about 18 hours to finish the first level. Much of the wait is held up in watching dwarves haul materials across the screen. While this *is* sped up by various spells and techs, the technology tends to be fairly expensive to produce (on level 1, I was using most of my resources to build a rail system to haul resources back to make railway carts and lines...); the portal spell is useful, but it gets to the point where your entire game experience is just managing portals to ensure the various dwarves don't take too long to get back home.Final issue: the tech tree is full of connections that map back onto each other, meaning you have to become skilled in all manner of furniture and decoration before you can advance from, say, iron to silver weapons or armour. Seems a bit absurd. While happiness seemed to be a factor in some sense, I never worked it out, so I ended up producing all sorts of spurious tapestries and chairs, and not actually using them, simply because the tech tree demanded it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												This game has a solid foundation, but has several major design flaws. Since the game already has a lot of positive reviews, I'll focus on why mine is negative.First off, it's extremely slow paced. It requires a lot of micro management, so you can't just set orders and go do something else. But it moves so slowly that you'll be sitting doing nothing for a minute or two after assigning new orders. Set some blocks to mine, trees to cut down, animals to hunt, then open portals near those places. Now wait 2 minutes while your dwarves finish those tasks. Then repeat. In order to play at an engaging speed, I actually used an external program to run the game at triple speed, which improved the game significantly.Second is the crafting "tree". All items, weapons, equipment, decoration, supplies, etc are bunched into groups of 4-5 items. In order to unlock a new group of items, you have to craft a certain number of items from the group (or two) that lead up to it. Crafting a lot of only one item from that group has diminishing returns, so it is best to craft 2-3 of each item in the group. The problem is, it isn't laid out in a tree. The next tier of armor might have furniture and glassware as prerequisites (as an example, I don't remember exactly). But each of THOSE requires 1-2 other groups first. So you can't rush to the items you want: you have to make EVERY ITEM IN THE GAME a few times to progress. This just compounds the first problem, slowing down the game. Even though you could easily just dig down and get mithril to make the best gear in the game, you can't actually craft those items until you've made every single other item in the game several times over. Imagine if in Minecraft, even though you can easily dig down and find diamonds in 10 minutes, you couldn't actually make diamond gear until you've spent 10 hours gathering materials and crafting every other in the game 20 times. Or if in Civilazation, there were no tech trees and you just had to research every single technology, in the same order, every game. That's what it feels like. There's no choice. It gets boring and tedious after the first time. Third is the lack of real progression from level to level in the campaign. There are four "worlds" in the campaign. Beat one, go to the next one. Here's the problem: each world only has a few new items to make. You play world one, get your dwarves decked out in the best gold and mithril gear, and then move on to world two... and you're back collecting sticks and leaves. World two lets you build four "ice" versions of other items, which are only better in that using ice doesn't waste the more valuable resources. Then you go through the whole crafting tree, taking forever to get enough resources to get up to gold and mithril again, so you can go on to world three and start all over again. World four finally adds some new weapons, which is nice, but they aren't a huge improvement on the same weapons you've been using since world one. It just doesn't feel like you're progressing. Normally in a campaign, when you move on to the next world you get access to stronger gear and the like. But in Craft the World, you work through the exact same progression over and over.My overall conclusion is that the game has potential but is poorly designed. A major overhaul could make it really good. Increasing dwarf movement speed so you don't have to micromanage portals for transportation would be amazing. Sorting the tech tree by item type would be a big help. Iron armor -> silver armor -> gold armor, instead of iron armor -> glassware -> fabric dying -> whatever -> silver armor or whatever the progression is. This would let you focus on what you want/need at the moment, instead of wasting your time making items you don't need first. When I need better armor so my dwarves can survive the next invasion, I don't want to have to make a ton of armoires first. The last major change would be changes to the scope of the campaign worlds. World one should be shorter, with iron as the only available metal, and weaker guardians that only require that iron gear to beat. Then world two is slightly larger, with silver added and guardians that require silver to beat. This way, the player actually feels a sense of progression from world to world. As is, it's just painful and quite frankly STUPID to go from mithril right back to wood, and then have to work back up to mithril. Also, don't make me unlock all the crap again in world two, three, four. It's a 100-200 hour game, with only 10-20 hours worth of content.Of course, for a lot of people it isn't just a game where you rush to beat the campaign. Like Minecraft, it's about building your vision of the perfect home. But in Minecraft, when you have a new vision you start a new world and can quickly have everything you need to start building again, but in Craft the World the tech system means that if you start a new world, it'll be at least 10 hours before you start to see your vision take shape.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												I have yet to finish it as i got sidetracked by larger RPG games (and other indies) but I will updeate this very short review once i have finished all three major maps, hence the following only is a first impression sort of deal after completing just the first level;This game is what i wanted both Towns and Minecraft to be. Except 2D-ish sidescroller with dwarves fighting off waves upon waves of undead and also veeery limited supply of certain metals meaning you have to be fairly greedy/careful with your metals. For me, in particular, iron, because you have to use it in so many different things including just research to unlock higher tier equiment and building blocks as well as necessary equipment, armour and weapons meaning you have to think while playing, not just breeze through it swiftly without putting any thought or effort into it.Pros:- Very replayable,- Not necessarily difficult but somewhat chance based how challenging the beginning will be depending on how you're placed on the map both strategically and practically considering resources.- Enjoyable graphics and style of animation.- Has to be learned. I had to restart games three times just to work out how to do things. First to learn how to build a house, second to actually build a house and have my dwarves not be miserable and hungry constantly. Third to build a house well and be able to defend it from the hordes. (Fourth: to learn not to attack or release the crystal guardian without a strategic vantage point AND high damage weapons/high defense armour equipped on ALL dwarves of which there should be et least 10. And fifth to actually win the map), Granted this may be considered a bad thing, but I rather enjoy the fact tht a game takes you being able to play the game in order to win it rather than just breezing through without that slight tickle in your belly when you're uncertain whether or not you'll be able to take on those enemies but you're aware you have no choice in the matter.- Although the tutorial doesn't hand you the game when you're fully able to understand what to do you have some idea and learn the rest through the objectives and through crafting so you're never fully alone in the game and left to your own vices althrough you are never told directly what to do next. Hence: the game encourages you to experiment and learn but will hold your hand and guide you a bit should you somehow manage to get stuck. - Mechanics run smoothly. I have not encountered any problems or major bugs this far.- Crafting is nice and smooth as well with a nice increasing level of dedication and involvement to craft higher tier object.Cons:- As in most my reviews, yet again the audio just gets really annoying after a few hours of playing... this far i can't really think of any other cons. As I progress i suspect I will come across more.Summary: Great fun. In fact. All of the fun. Despite the fact that I find myself moaning and ♥♥♥♥♥ing about how much I hate each dwarf in my colony (by name), Possibly also verbally assualting them with graphic curses and promises of torment after a few hours in a map it is still one of the most enjoyable and involved games i've played in a long while.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2014
												I originaly wrote a review that reccomended this game with a dose of skepticism.  I'm now rewriting that review after having many hours in game.  This game is boring.  Very boring.  It's obviously being designed as a port to touch screen devices.  They even have a handy gold coin store in place (currently you randomly find these coins while digging or by killing certain enemies).  This game is all about finding the most efficient setup and then recreating it in a different level time after time after time.  It desperately needs some variety.  The "tech tree" makes almost no sense and some items are even missing from it.  The crafting interface is horrible with a 3x3 grid where you have to drag each individual component over one at a time, even if it's the same component.  Unless it happens to be in an adjacent slot, in which case you can double click the original piece and fill them in.  This game feels like it could be something much more fun but only with a lot of polish, creativity (I'm looking at you arrow/tesla towers gimmie some more options here), and dedication to a specific platform instead of using PC as a way to play test your obviously touch screen intended game.

content:
Posted: May 16, 2015
												I started playing craft the world just recently and have enjoyed most of the time spent on it, there are a few bugs and interface improvements to make but for the most part its a good game worth it's price.It looks very good and remind me of a few other games like dungeon keeper, minecraft and games like dwarf fortress and there is a risk that you will postpone bedtime to spend only one more hour to complete your latest mastermind design. There is more then meets the eye here and planning your shelter and redesign it as you progress is both fun and rewarding. I only played custom games so far and even if the endgame tend to drag out a bit on large maps I didn't feel like it was to bad and never lacked resources for long. (Lucky perhaps?)What could be improved is the AI that can from time to time drive you nuts when the dwarfs do one stupid thing after another, there could be improvements to be made with tooltips and make it more obvious what armor stats your dwarfs have when you equip better gear. Other thing is that the tech tree could be tuned a bit to make it a bit more interesting and some techs should be moved to a earlier spot in the tech tree to match your progress as you need to expand and go further away from the shelter (elevator, secondary storages and railtracks for example) . I would also love to see some more options for defending your shelter, like more turrets, burning oil, perhaps a drawbridge. If you are into sandbox games and enjoy perfecting your castle and exploring the landscape around it you should be quite happy with this game, it got much to offer even though there are room for improvements.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												After putting in 85 hours of this I should probably write a review...Craft The World is this little hidden gem of a game, combining the lighter sides of both Dwarf Fortress and Terraria in a well polished, enjoyable game. It's one of the few games this year where I've found myself coming back to the game time and time again to indulge in a day of play. Currently it seems to be updated pretty regularly, and the new addition of being able to start rudimentary animal husbandry was a really nice, needed touch. The aesthetic of the game is wonderful - the graphics are just really pleasing to look and the game just oozes it's own unique charm. In all my time of play I've not noticed huge bugs at all, certainly nothing game breaking. There's a really nice touch in that your games are saved on Steam's cloud, so I can load it up elsewhere and just play the same worlds I was on. There are a few cons - the comment that it doesn't have high replayability is a fair one, as once you've beaten a world you've no reason other than pure enjoyment to play the same type of world again. Once you've run out of tech tree there's not so much left to do and mythril will run out eventually. There's no real incentive to build your base beyond straightforward utility - comfort is not so hard to max out provided your walls are of a decent material and it's also far easier to build down instead of up (In fairness though, they are dwarves...). If you have some items they can't pick up, they'll spam broken pathway thoughts all day but give you no clue as to where they are. Finally, and most annoyingly, you will have to craft several of the same item over and over again to get the tech tree to progress. This leads to a bit of a block in the middle section that you'll just have to persevere through.But really, these are just gripes and most of my wants in this game would be wishlists as opposed to game changes. I'd love to see an expansion of the world types - perhaps a fire-type world or a rainforest. I'd also love to see the class roles solidified and with the ability to task those dwarves. For example; disable everyone who isn't a hunter from hunting animals; make it so that only cooks and smiths and carpenters can carry out those tasks. Maybe get some unique 'appearance sets' so everyone doesn't look like a mythril statue in end game?To summarize, if 2D building and defending is your poison, you really can't go wrong with this game. It's well polished, enjoyable, and has its own unique charm. Glad I stumbled across it.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												Worth every penny. (Or Cent, or whatever currency you think in...)Synopsis: An addictive game where you direct your dwarves to excavate, (For resources), chop, mine, dig, plant, build structures and craft items to complete given levels.There are some magic abilities, like portals which come in handy for speeding up travel, a fiery fireball to roast enemies, and even summon imps to carry goods, freeing up the dwarves for more intensive labor.But this is not just about magic, it i about dwarves, which are known for engineering feats of note, so you can build a railway, allowing your dwarfs to speed from one end of the map to the other, lifts, that essentially do the same, just in a vertical direction.Your dwarves are also skilled in different fighting and crafting skills, like archers, sword wielders, mages and those swinging big meat tenderisers. Crafting skills range from fishing, milling, tree felling, to even simpler forms like swimming and mountain climbing.You need to equip your dwarves with the right tools, and so you craft things like axes, pickaxes, weapons, armour and t tools like backpacks.I've had endless fun, and plenty frustration with this game. At the tim of this writing, I am hinting for the last 6 achievements.This game has elements of Terraria in it, and is a bit of a world builder, as it allows you to craft elaborate homes for the dwarves.The combat is awesome,  but at times frustrating, as they keep attacking when I am busy exploring and excavating for resources.The tech tree does not make sense sometimes, however, I think there is only one point where it becomes a real pain to complete, which is the second last tier, for crafting potions. Having crafted the potions though, helps immensely in the coming final guardian battles.The last improvements made, look great, even though I haven't tried them yet.I disagree with some of the game design elements, however, these "problems" i perceive, do not distract from an awesome gaming experience, with plenty of fun.I am a great supporter of management games, where you direct, and the minions follow, and this game falls squarely into that bracket.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												Craft the World is a nice mix of Tower Defence, Base Building and Resource Gathering / Management and after 200 hours of play I can safely say that I have gotten great value for money with this game!You are constantly moving forward one way or another. With a vast tech tree to work through, there is always something new to craft, new weapons, new tools and new decorations are plentiful. Ever increasing waves of an enemy horde will keep you on your toes, complete with a countdown so you know how long you have left to bolster defences and get ready for the pending invasion. Also the main aim of the game is to build a portal and move on to the next new land, for this you must find and defeat the boss creatures hidden in the depth of the world, be careful when digging deep though and more than 1 surprise awaits in the far depths.You are never left bored, not only are you mining to find the Portal (and to gather resources) while waiting for the invading horde but enemies will spawn in unlit areas and the day/night cycle will bring a small horde of enemies to your door each night.There are plenty of tools, weapons and armours for your dwarves to choose from ranging from stone and wooden stuff to mythril, do you go for style over functionality? will your dwarves be melee warriors, archers or mages? finding a balance that suits you can mean the difference between success and failure when attacking strong enemies.Building a home for your dwarves is also important, keep them happy by giving them good food (and maybe a nice little something to drink ;) )and a nice place to live, there are loads of choices in this department, from various walls and floors to fish bowls and comfy chairs. So much to choose from keeps the game fresh.This is a game I always go back to and I highly recommend it to anyone who likes tower defence or resource management games.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												After putting in 85 hours of this I should probably write a review...Craft The World is this little hidden gem of a game, combining the lighter sides of both Dwarf Fortress and Terraria in a well polished, enjoyable game. It's one of the few games this year where I've found myself coming back to the game time and time again to indulge in a day of play. Currently it seems to be updated pretty regularly, and the new addition of being able to start rudimentary animal husbandry was a really nice, needed touch. The aesthetic of the game is wonderful - the graphics are just really pleasing to look and the game just oozes it's own unique charm. In all my time of play I've not noticed huge bugs at all, certainly nothing game breaking. There's a really nice touch in that your games are saved on Steam's cloud, so I can load it up elsewhere and just play the same worlds I was on. There are a few cons - the comment that it doesn't have high replayability is a fair one, as once you've beaten a world you've no reason other than pure enjoyment to play the same type of world again. Once you've run out of tech tree there's not so much left to do and mythril will run out eventually. There's no real incentive to build your base beyond straightforward utility - comfort is not so hard to max out provided your walls are of a decent material and it's also far easier to build down instead of up (In fairness though, they are dwarves...). If you have some items they can't pick up, they'll spam broken pathway thoughts all day but give you no clue as to where they are. Finally, and most annoyingly, you will have to craft several of the same item over and over again to get the tech tree to progress. This leads to a bit of a block in the middle section that you'll just have to persevere through.But really, these are just gripes and most of my wants in this game would be wishlists as opposed to game changes. I'd love to see an expansion of the world types - perhaps a fire-type world or a rainforest. I'd also love to see the class roles solidified and with the ability to task those dwarves. For example; disable everyone who isn't a hunter from hunting animals; make it so that only cooks and smiths and carpenters can carry out those tasks. Maybe get some unique 'appearance sets' so everyone doesn't look like a mythril statue in end game?To summarize, if 2D building and defending is your poison, you really can't go wrong with this game. It's well polished, enjoyable, and has its own unique charm. Glad I stumbled across it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												After playing other attempts at turning the Dwarf Fortress formula into an easily swallowable pill like Gnomoria and Towns, I feel that this is the first that succeeds all-around. It's a game with simple interface, but still plenty of depth. Dwarves behave in a relatively intelligent manner without you having to micro-manage priorities or wondering why that one task you assigned just isn't getting done, you say it, they do it. And even if there is something you want done straight away, you can always take control of a dwarf directly and do it yourself, or set down a portal to get them closer to what you want them to do. In the campaign, unlockable tech-trees and finding pieces to the portal to the next world give you goals to shoot for, and even after that, there's always something more to improve upon when building your current world.-Notes on Difficulty:- As you play you will be beset by waves of enemies periodically to test your defenses, at first I felt a little worried, but unless you are in permadeath mode, your game won't end even if your very last dwarf dies. Worst case scenario, you lose all your dwarves and the skills they built up, but they will quickly be replaced and they can wear all your previous dwarves equipment. You can quickly repair any destroyed blocks from the previous attack and prepare better for the next one.I highly recommend this for anyone who enjoys Dwarf Fortress, or is even simply interested in it but feels a little overwhelmed. I am hoping for more objects/biomes/creatures in the future!UPDATE: Occasional slowdown if you have too many tasks queued or too many objects on the map, enemy and dwarf pathing isn't perfect, but you can build around it to accommodate them.TIP: You can use F1 to F3 to alter game speed. Important!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												WOW! I mean seriously! WOW!ImpressionThis game is just simply amazing! I bought it while it was on sale, however, I would gladly have payed full price. The game is currently in early access phase. Sometimes, with early access there is definitely some bugs or some issues with the game. This is true at this point. But the issues are minor enough that I really don’t mind a lot. I’m sure they will iron them out and if they don’t, the game is still amazing and I would still pay full price. What is it?	This game has some definite parallels to popular games such as Terraria. That isn’t a bad thing either. The success of Terraria is undeniable. I have played many hours of that game myself. This is NOT a terraria clone however. This has similar features and gameplay models but it is far from the same. In this game you are more of a dwarf god in that you tell them to chop a tree down and they go to work. You don’t have one character to traverse the world with, you control multiple characters to tell what to do and watch the magic. Still want that control of being a character? Don’t worry, they got you covered. You can individually control the dwarfs as well. There are also a lot of great twists on old enemies as well as some spectacular new ones. Did I mention there is also experience and reward as such? This is great since nothings is worse then the same old dwarf with the same old abilities. You can also outfit your cool warriors with armor, weapons, tools, fishing poles, and so much more. The goal is to survive and thrive into a great dwarf community. I have over 5 hours of play time as of now and that’s what I know so far. I’m absolutely amazed at how good this game is.Buy or Fly?	The ultimate question you’re probably asking yourself is, “Should I buy this damn game or not?” Well, if you like boring straightforward cookie cutter games with absolutely predictable gameplay, then don’t buy this game. If you like fun, new and creative ways to play a mix of genres, then this is a MUST BUY! I would absolutely recommend this game. This game is on iPhone and iPad?! Buy or Fly?	Silly question. YES! I bought it on both Steam and my iPhone/iPad already! It’s the same game on both but a slightly different experience. Either one is worth buying but I say buy both!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												I am in love with this game, the sort of game you can leave for a week and just pick up where you left off.... And you will have to! There is no playing a single level in one sitting (unless I'm really bad at this game)...I am STILL on level 2 and have clocked 50 hours!Basically you are micro managing  a small population of dwarves - you order them to cut trees, mine ore, kill enemies etc... All while building a house with good comfort so that dwarves sleep well and gain health back faster. Every 45 minutes you get a wave of monsters which gets harder and more portals will start opening. So it's a micro managing - tower defence - creativity - mining game!!! You can also make equipement and kit out each dwarf. It is in my top five games.My only cons are that Dwarves hang around an awful lot even if you have ordered them to do things, sometimes its just faster to control one manually. I don't like how they drop all of their items to ALL go and attack a snail if you accidently click on it and I also get infuriated when a dwarf decides to take the long and treacherous route home instead of the portal! BUT seriously, those are just irks lol! LOVE this game, worth every penny. The app is pretty good too but it's a couple of updates behind.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 8, 2016
												This is hands down one of the best games I've played in years.  Easily in the top dozen of my life with Homeworld, Civilizaiton 1/2, Warlords, C&C, FTL, Sea Battle.  It's all about finding the right balance and creating meaningful progression and this game has done it.  Not perfect of course (is anything?) but pretty damn close.Pros- Pretty deep game with the four worlds with lots of hours.- Increased options and strategies with the DLC- Really nice balance between strategic choices and RTS fun- Okay replayability with the four core maps plus creating custom games- No big bugs, very stable game and small bugs are only slightly annoying and easily overcome- Appears to be a developer who listens and cares about the community they've built - I have lots of hope for more DLC and an eventual sequelCons- multiplayer is a little awkward as its inserted into single player games- Dwarves are a little flat from an RPG perspective - three skills per dwarf.  I'd like to see personalities like grumpy dwarf, sleepy dwarf as a simple way to create a stronger conneciton with them.- Some simple techniques can eliminate most of the risk from invading monsters.  Needs a bit more balance here.- More rare/unique items dropped by big monsters would be cool, more tower options would create more defence optionsAmazing game and worth the full price (and even better on sale).   I'd recommend getting the DLC with the game as it's nice to start the game with the additional options created by the DLC.Happy gaming.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												This game has a solid foundation, but has several major design flaws. Since the game already has a lot of positive reviews, I'll focus on why mine is negative.First off, it's extremely slow paced. It requires a lot of micro management, so you can't just set orders and go do something else. But it moves so slowly that you'll be sitting doing nothing for a minute or two after assigning new orders. Set some blocks to mine, trees to cut down, animals to hunt, then open portals near those places. Now wait 2 minutes while your dwarves finish those tasks. Then repeat. In order to play at an engaging speed, I actually used an external program to run the game at triple speed, which improved the game significantly.Second is the crafting "tree". All items, weapons, equipment, decoration, supplies, etc are bunched into groups of 4-5 items. In order to unlock a new group of items, you have to craft a certain number of items from the group (or two) that lead up to it. Crafting a lot of only one item from that group has diminishing returns, so it is best to craft 2-3 of each item in the group. The problem is, it isn't laid out in a tree. The next tier of armor might have furniture and glassware as prerequisites (as an example, I don't remember exactly). But each of THOSE requires 1-2 other groups first. So you can't rush to the items you want: you have to make EVERY ITEM IN THE GAME a few times to progress. This just compounds the first problem, slowing down the game. Even though you could easily just dig down and get mithril to make the best gear in the game, you can't actually craft those items until you've made every single other item in the game several times over. Imagine if in Minecraft, even though you can easily dig down and find diamonds in 10 minutes, you couldn't actually make diamond gear until you've spent 10 hours gathering materials and crafting every other in the game 20 times. Or if in Civilazation, there were no tech trees and you just had to research every single technology, in the same order, every game. That's what it feels like. There's no choice. It gets boring and tedious after the first time. Third is the lack of real progression from level to level in the campaign. There are four "worlds" in the campaign. Beat one, go to the next one. Here's the problem: each world only has a few new items to make. You play world one, get your dwarves decked out in the best gold and mithril gear, and then move on to world two... and you're back collecting sticks and leaves. World two lets you build four "ice" versions of other items, which are only better in that using ice doesn't waste the more valuable resources. Then you go through the whole crafting tree, taking forever to get enough resources to get up to gold and mithril again, so you can go on to world three and start all over again. World four finally adds some new weapons, which is nice, but they aren't a huge improvement on the same weapons you've been using since world one. It just doesn't feel like you're progressing. Normally in a campaign, when you move on to the next world you get access to stronger gear and the like. But in Craft the World, you work through the exact same progression over and over.My overall conclusion is that the game has potential but is poorly designed. A major overhaul could make it really good. Increasing dwarf movement speed so you don't have to micromanage portals for transportation would be amazing. Sorting the tech tree by item type would be a big help. Iron armor -> silver armor -> gold armor, instead of iron armor -> glassware -> fabric dying -> whatever -> silver armor or whatever the progression is. This would let you focus on what you want/need at the moment, instead of wasting your time making items you don't need first. When I need better armor so my dwarves can survive the next invasion, I don't want to have to make a ton of armoires first. The last major change would be changes to the scope of the campaign worlds. World one should be shorter, with iron as the only available metal, and weaker guardians that only require that iron gear to beat. Then world two is slightly larger, with silver added and guardians that require silver to beat. This way, the player actually feels a sense of progression from world to world. As is, it's just painful and quite frankly STUPID to go from mithril right back to wood, and then have to work back up to mithril. Also, don't make me unlock all the crap again in world two, three, four. It's a 100-200 hour game, with only 10-20 hours worth of content.Of course, for a lot of people it isn't just a game where you rush to beat the campaign. Like Minecraft, it's about building your vision of the perfect home. But in Minecraft, when you have a new vision you start a new world and can quickly have everything you need to start building again, but in Craft the World the tech system means that if you start a new world, it'll be at least 10 hours before you start to see your vision take shape.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								Actually very fun. While it may seem similar to Terraria, the game plays differently and has a different aesthetic that reminds this author much more of Dungeon Keeper crossed with Dwarf Fortress. This game is entertaining and engaging despite the field of "Dwarf-likes" being flooded currently. Despite some very odd design decisions and a 2d space, the game stays novel by reducing some of the complex factors of Dwarf Fortress (goblin invasions etc) to a point where they become somewhat stale after a bit. Despite that, the game stays fun by introducing some new surprises in the depths and simplifying gameplay mechanics within a 2d space.

												I did not like this game the first time I saw it. But having watched a couple of let's plays I got really tempted and eventually purchased this game. I have not played much, but my first impression is pleasant. Interesting gameplay, full freedom and really challenging game mechanic - the more you play (provided you play actively), the more dwarfs you will get. It will increase your power, but on the other hand, all of those dwarfs should be fed, given place to sleep, given tools and weapons. Maybe this game was inspired by Terraria and Minecraft, but it is quite different. In Minecraft, theoretically, you can beat the game even if you live in a small house. In Craft the world, you'll have to expand. 15 dwarfs need space to live afterall!I am really looking forward to developers adding even more items into the game, hopefully they'll include some steampunk-themed things. Because I've always assosiated dwarfs with steampunk.Some'll say Terraria is better. Maybe, I have not played it, I can not say. But why control one character when you can have an entire army?This is a wonderful game, and even after 1.5 hours of gameplay I am like:

												This is a great little game.  It is by far the best Early Access Game I have purchased.  The crafting element is very well done and a lot of fun,  The combat is also well done. I can't wait till the game is finished up.____________________________________________________________So the game has gone to full release since my original review and I have a few more hours playing it...Here is my take on the finished product and the first DLC.It is a still great game overall and I still highly recomend it as a fun mostly casual game.  It also is still the best Early Access Game I have.Pros:  Good graphics  Good single player gameplay  It has been out for almost 2 years and still gets updated above and beyond the DLC  The DLC was reasonalby priced for what was in it (female dwarves, decorative wall    tiles, catapults, shields, and 2 house pets)Cons:  The Dwarves AI is still not the sharpest tool in the shed, though it has improved  Multiplayer gets poor reviews that I have seen, I was unable to get it working and    multiplayer is not important to me so your milage may vary  The game occasionally still has some non-fatal bugs that are fixed by quiting out and    restarting  There is a lot of dragging in the crafting interface  IOS version available, but no android version

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												[edit]How sweet, they introduced rats in the latest update, and the solution to get rid of rats via paid DLC. Thanks devs, thats a real insentive to keep playing this game :(After spending a long time playing Minecraft and Terraria, I started looking for a new game with similar playing experience and that would hook me in just like those ones. Craft The World seemed to do just that, and once I started playing I found myself sucked in and spending long hours immersed, at least until I completed the first world.The game is very enjoyable to play, easy and intuitive to learn. It’s fun to command around your army of cute little dumb dwarfs. And dumb they are, sometimes amusing you with their complete goofiness and sometimes testing your patience to the limit, as they so often seem to refuse collaboration. They have a persistent tendency of being in the wrong place. Command your dwarfs to build something, and you can be sure all other idle dwarfs will run to that same spot and stand there doing nothing, just hampering the dwarf who is actually trying to do the building. Relax your attention for a moment, and the dwarves may wander off getting lost into caves or falling down to their deaths into pits full of critters.All this fun will last you through the first world though, as you will have to start from scratch once you beat the first world and start the second one. All the long hours you spent grinding through the tech tree, collecting resources, upgrading and training your dwarfs will all be lost once you make it through the portal to the next world.This is a major drawback of this game, as it gives you little reason to keep on playing after the first world. It’s frustrating to have to start over, and not being able to keep your dwarves and tech upgrades. I don’t mind arriving at a new world to build and explore, but starting everything all over from point zero with one dwarf and no tech was enough for me to put the game down for good.Another part of the game mechanics that makes little sense is the huge tech tree you have to work through in order to get access to better equipment. Many of the items you are forced to craft in order to advance are completely useless (mirrors, decorative items, columns, statues, gargoyles...). These useless items should not be mandatory.It would also be nice to be able to assign individual tasks to a dwarf or group of dwarves, as the current game only allows tasks to be assigned collectively. This task assignment is not always efficient – sometimes a dwarf standing right next to a assigned task will do nothing while another dwarf will come from far away to complete that task.I can say without any doubt that I enjoyed playing this game and that the 30 hours+ spent to finish the first world were worth the money I paid for it, but I wish there had been a way to continue the game without losing everything I conquered.Maybe the developers will correct these issues in a future update, as it has been a major source of complaint among players.

								This game caught me off guard. Didn't think I'd get so hooked so fast. It's just a really solid and fun game. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								Overall a fun game with a charming art style as well as an interesting dynamic to tech progression that is both probably the game's biggest strength, as well as most glaring weakness. The tech tree is vast and full of neat things to craft and place around or give to your dwarves, but around the halfway point tech progression can slow to a crawl as you scrounge up materials for your seventh soup ladle or umpteenth stone pillar that you won't ever use while desperately trying to claw your way to better weapons and armour so that poor Hunck the blacksmith doesn't get maimed by a beholder for the third time today.This mechanic, while it can be slow-going and grindy at points, does however ensure there's never a lack of things to do while you wait for your bearded minions to finish the latest addon to your fortress or figure out the best manner in which to club a snail to death.The generally casual pace makes this game an excellent time-waster for when you've got nothing to do and a long time to do it while the regular invasions that occur every 40 minutes or so keep things interesting and keep you on your toes and devising clever methods to keep enemies out of your fort and your dwarves' heads firmly on their shoulders.If invasions and tech trees aren't your thing, the game also boasts a sandbox mode, though I personally haven't taken the time to play much with it.Updates and hot fixes are small and frequent, with constant effort being put into improving AI, visual assets, and the overall gameplay experience.Also ghosts are pretty much jerks.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game felt very polished compared to so many other games in 'Early Access'. I am very much looking forward to whatever else they plan on implementing.  The game definitely has that Terreria feel but I very much enjoy the dynamic of controlling multiple dwarfs and being able to mold each of them in to their own specific role.  The game also gives you a similar feel of control to the 'hand of god' games such as Black & White, though when you really need to, you can take direct control of a dwarf.  One other little detail that I appreciated was the fact that the dwarfs can be clumbsy and may fall of planks or off walls and take damage.  This attention to detail made the dwarfs feel much more like a believable character than just one of many bots that will run around and do your bidding with no faulter.I could go on about the features that I enjoy about this game (and at the time of writing this I have only played it for just over 3 hours) but I would highly suggest you play it for yourself.

Early Access Review
								All in all, this is a very very good game considering it is still curently only in early access! I havent yet encountered any bugs to my surprise and this game certainly has a lot of potential to be expanded upon, not that there isnt already plenty there for the time being!The only VERY minor problem I have with this game is the difficulty, in that as you progress through the game, it doesn't seem to get much harder as you develop, to the point where even on a game with the difficulty set to nightmare, I am having very little trouble with monsters including the large waves that appear every so often once you reach roughly about the 2 hour mark. The other thing I feel that woild make a good improvement would be the ability to switch at somepoint from a standard game to a permant death game, and then be unable to reverse, as following my above comment, it is quite easy to have a dwarf die in the early stages of the game, but once you reach the stage where you have a base up and running with multiple dwarves, the game does become easier, and I think this may reintroduce some of the challange back into the game at a later stage.However as I said these are very minor points, and all in all a very fun game that has plenty of content and is really promising. I highly recommend this game!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
Early Access Review
I really want to like this gameThis type of game is something I enjoy. And this game looks like it will become a great game if the developers keep developing it. However, as it stands right now, it has very limited depth. The tech tree seems out of sorts. It's difficult to survive in the beginning due to being unable to build adequate shelter before the first invasion.Invasions get harder as the game progresses. That's great. Except they only get harder in so far as there are more mobs in each invasion. At some point, you will be unable to complete an invasion before daylight. I have all of my guys with maxed out weapons and high levels of experience with them. I have multiple defenseive structures. I still can't complete an invasion. There are other points of contention: Dwarf AI is lackluster at best. Minerals become very rare. Towards the end of the game, it's nigh impossible to gather enough materials to equip you dwarves, much less build grand castles under the mountains. There is no way to automate anything. This includes things like making sure tables are stocked with food. Transit AI is terrible, and in some situations is so broken that you have to manually remove them and replace them in order to get them to work properly.Perhaps in the future, this game will become a fun game to play. Until then, play the first hour or so, and then go find something better than the tedium that is Craft the World.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								Been playing this game nonstop since I got it. Very VERY polished and playable game especially for Steam's notorious Early Access program. This game has more content and is more stable than many indie full releases here on Steam.A mix of Terraria's 2D world with Dwarf Fortress' dwarves and industries along with a dose of Minecraft-style box crafting interface. This sounds awful, but first it's not eye-destroying because the entire game has a hand-drawn art style and not the overdone pixel-y aststyle of games like it. Resources seem to be plentiful but there is definite challenge in the waves of enemies that spawn above ground and you find underground. Defnitely a fun base building game thats easy to get a grasp on and also is easy to make awesome looking bases in. I love it so far, it has a massive tech tree to work through BUT one aspect of the otherwise great UI bugs me to no end. This game has an absolutely enormous amount of objects to put in the hotbar and all of them are only accessible through another menu that is tabbed. So it can take forever to exchange the items you need into the hotbar. Hopefully that issue is fixed before the game leaves Early Access.Otherwise, STRIKE THE EARTH (and spiders, goblins, zombies, etc)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								My ten-hours-in review: it was rough figuring out how things worked initially.  It doesn't explain some important things (like how to build "shelter") but if you dig a little online, it's easy to get sorted out, and I believe that the menus will probably be improved.  That being said, once I got the game sorted out after a couple hours of fiddling, I started really enjoying myself.  It's a pretty forgiving game so far, and I've taken quite a shine to my little tribe of dwarves.  I can relax and enjoy the exploration without feeling like one of my guys will get stupid and fall in a lake of fire.  The waves of monsters from time to time have been something of a challenge, but I have yet to see what happens if you get wiped out.  Individual dwarves respawn after a delay when killed.  All in all, it's an enjoyable little time waster, and you like build and explore games, there's a lot to like here.  I heartily recommend it.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												Probably one of my favorite games on Steam, as evidenced by my time played. Very addicting, the interface is simple, and it is very easy to get things going. There is plenty of room for creativity with base building, and the graphics and audio are pleasant.Multiplayer still needs some work, though the developer has tweaked it since releasing this feature, which indicates they are aware multiplayer needs improvement. On the other hand, single player is where this game shines. My other suggestion for improvement would be a slightly better tutorial. It took me a while in the beginning to figure out how to build a house properly, and there should also be a bit more guidance on how to work the campaign quests (particularly how to beat the first mission, as the others are pretty similar, albeit located in larger worlds/more diverse ecosystems).Wholeheartedly recommend!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
												I've put in over 30 hours.  I'm not even crafting mithril weapons and armor yet.  Instead, I'm growing wheat to make beer.  The dwarves love beer and consume lots of it.Oh yeah, there is the monster portal that opens every 45 minutes.  Every time I survive, I tell myself I should go to bed.  Next thing I know, there is 7 minutes left until the next portal opens and I've upgraded armor or weapons and think I should try it out...just one more time.The dwarf AI is not great - however, that's part of the charm.  You have to save these guys.  Build signs to deter them or craft doors (and lock them).  I've enjoyed my time in it.  It's fun.  If you like Terraria and/or crafting games, give it a chance.Update:  I'm now over 175 hours into the game.  It's an obsession.  The tech tree is huge - I've built everything and am on the last part of the campaign.  I've learned to hate the ghosts and gargoyles.  They are annoying.  I more than got my money out of this game.  However, I've learned it's not for everyone.  The game can be tedious at times.  You will also get frustrated with the AI - it can make some really poor choices.  You will also hate the damn ghost - I'd like to just turn them off.  I don't see the point.Wish list if there is ever a "part 2":-Upgradable tower defenses.  Yes, we have the archer tower and tesla-thing.  I would like more.-What about adding golems?  I wouldn't mind having some that could haul materials, patrol, and perhaps even do some mining.  Once you start crafting silver armor - the game shifts and requires you to mine lots of metals.  I have been giving orders that take 30 minutes or so - I do something else while they are mining.  This is tedious and gets boring.

Posted: December 2, 2015
												This game is pretty awesome.  Nothing too fancy, but just enough to enjoy and kill time.  This game is a mix of Terraria and Minecraft.  Game itself has a pretty easy learning curve.  The digging, crafting, and fighting is fairly easy, that my 9 year old does it better than me.  Graphics is okay for the type of game it is.  A very enjoyable game.  If you enjoy and appreciate Terraria and Minecraft type game, then you'll enjoy Craft the World.

												This game is all in all fun. Every time I start playing it I just keep going and never stop. It's the kind of building game I like where you control a nice amount of characters and they do tasks on they own when you tell what they are. And the fact that it gets challenging is pretty nice too, as long as it doesn't get too hard.But there is this one thing about this game that bothers me a bit. The tech tree. It forces you to make stuff you probably won't even place down at all. Something they could do to make it so you don't have 10+ items in your inventory that won't be placed is to give the shop a sell function or something similar.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
												Really nice game, totally worth its price.Nothing really new, but it does what you paid for, and it does it quite well. Although:- The art could be a little bit enhanced (Artworks for loading screen and menu for instance, look a bit cheap).- More music would be nice. You can spend hours on a single map, and just one or two music looping is rapidly annoying.- A better AI for the dwarves would be a great enhancement. I know it's not an easy thing to do, but sometimes, they do some really stupid things like drowning or running into a pack of monsters just to pick up dirt, etc.- But the only real problem i have with this game is the fact that, when you've spent hours and hours on a map (collecting everything you can, maxing you dwarves, creating everything you can) and you go on the next level, you have to start all over from scratch with nothing from the previous map you came from. Even the blueprints of the objects must be unlocked again, and this is really annoying.Still, i've spent about 60 hours on this game so far, so money well spent, and i think the devs love this game enough to make it even better so i'm looking forward the next updates.

												Craft the World was a game I found through a youtuber named Paul. The game is a way better version of Terraria and thats why I love it. The game can get pretty difficult and frusterating. But, what makes up for that is the fact that the dwarves are total and utter ding-dongs. Its hilarious. I love the crafting and building aspect of the game. I wish that the first world in the Campaine was a little bigger. Overall, its a great game and I cant wait to see what kind of things will be added in the future.
